book.materiality_desc: Course navy blue cover with faux-leather burgundy binding. There is a black and white photograph of a lake and mountains pasted onto the front cover likely clipped from a  magazine (possibly showing the Highlands or the Lake District). The photograph shows signs of wear, including a small hole worn in the middle of the photograph. Inside the front cover, a small sticker states that the book was made by R.B. Thomson Stationer, Printer and Bookbinder, 12 West Nile Street, Glasgow. The scrapbook paper is ruled with pink and blue lines (blue ruling lines running horizontally and pink margins). The pages are bound in groups and have mottled edges.
book.notes: Although Morgan gives this book that date range 1931-1953, he also notes the early materials for this book were rearranged from small blotters in 1937.

pages.desc: Cover page for Scrapbook 1. Written on the page are metadata notes by Morgan, including Morgan's name ("Edwin G. Morgan") and the date range listed as "Span: 1931-1953 (Rearranged+ 1937)" and " +i.e. collected from various small jotters". Under this, Morgan has included a clipping that reads "1931 A D = the year 1 F S", a clipping reading "BEFORE I GO HENCE", handwritten lines that read "Donner soulas à notre vie / Qui bientôt nous sera ravie", and a clipping from Milton's Paradise Lost that reads "A Wilderness of sweets; for Nature here / Wantond as in her prime, and plaid at will / Her Virgin Fancies, pouring forth more sweet,/ Wilde above rule or art; enormous bliss". Also included is a black and white reproduction of della Francesca's c.1470 painting 'Nativity', a black and white photograph of a bear lying on its back and touching its front paws to its back paws, a black and white insignia bearing the initials "R.A.", and a colour photograph of a sculpted horned object.

Sparse page with two smaller clippings and one large clipping. The large clipping is a black and white reproduction of a drawing by Wu Wei depicting a woman and a phoenix, captioned "Fairy and Phoenix. By Wu Wei. (1458-1508 A.D.) Ink, lightly coloured, on silk. 58 in. by 37 1/2 in.". The clipping above the Wei reproduction is a text-based clipping, which reads "OUTER WORLD AND INNER LIFE / By these things men live. In all these is the life of my spirit". Below the reproduction is a black and white photograph of a fish.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodlesMorgan has drawn some small ink drawings on the scrapbook page in bright blue ink
pages.desc: A page that is predominantly textual, focused on excerpts from Haldane's "On Being the Right Size" and touches on research being done in Russia to use plants and agriculture information to determine the age of civilizations. Morgan has also included a second clipping from Haldane, which Morgan has annotated with "JBS HALDANE" and which reads "Thus I regard it as interesting that after taking the largest quantity of calcium chloride on record, I dreamt that Edward Lear had written and illustrated a life of Christ. It was a strange book, but not essentially irreverent. Unfortunately, the only detail of it which remains clearly in my memory is Pontius Pilate's moustache." Other small clippings are scattered around the larger sections of text, including a French language clipping from Banville's poem "Lapins",  reading "Nous sommes les tendres Lapins / Assis sur leurs petits derrières", two separate clippings with lines from Thomas's "To the Memory of Sir Isaac Newton", one reading "Dreaming in whispering groves, by the hoarse brook"  and the other reading "That now he wanders through those endless worlds", lines from "The Nut-Brown Maid" reading "O lord, what is this worldys blysse that changeth as the mone!/ My somers day in lusty may is derked before the none. / I here you say, farewell: Nay, nay, we depart nat so sone./ Why say ye so? Wheder wyll ye go? Alas! What have ye done?/ All my welfare to sorrowe and care sholde change, yf ye were gone;/ For in my mynde, of all mankynde I love by you alone",  and two excerpts from Beowulf, one reading "pyrs sceal on fęnne" and the other reading "lagu drūsade,/ waeter under wolcnum waeldrēore fāg".  Other clippings include a text-based clipping that reads "Tree ornaments are made out of blown glass, and the quicksilver is put inside afterward", a text-based clipping reading "St. Paul's is moving West, down Ludgate Hill 'at the rate of about one inch every hundred years", a text-based clipping reading "To couple is a custome,/ all things thereto agree:/ Why should I not, then, love/ since love to all is free", a sepia-toned photograph of a stand of trees, a black and white image that is difficult to make out, a black and white clipping that may be handwritten showing ornate characters, a black and white photograph of a carved head from a statue or other similar artifact, and a text-based clipping reading "54. It can in no case be said that heaven is out of anyone, but that it is within him; for every angel receives the heaven which is around him according to the heaven which is within him". This last clipping has been pasted on top of two other decorative clippings that are almost wholly obscured, one black and white and one colour.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodlesSmall ink doodles by Morgan
pages.desc: Page focused on two illustrated articles from an "Animals in Legends" series from Zoo Magazine, one titled "The Barnacle Goose" and the other "The Halcyon". The Barnacle Goose is a legendary animal that is said to grow on certain trees, especially in the Orkneys. The Ahlcyon article discusses legends of the kingfisher through the story of Halcyon, "daughter of Aeolus and wife of Ceyx, [who] threw herself inot the sea in her grief after the shipwreck of her husband." Onto "The Barnacle Goose" clipping, Morgan has pasted two small clippings, one reading "Disraeli had a little bag, / built on the Gladstone plan, / but the name upon the label was / H. Titherington Mann" and the other describing the hatching of a four-legged chicken in Yugo-Slavia, which Morgan has annotated as being from the Observer. Four smaller text clippings are pasted around the two larger clippings: one from Wordsworth's "Yew-Trees", reading "To lie, and listen to the mountain flood/ Murmuring from Glaramara's inmost/ caves",  one from Lyle's drama Campaspe, reading "They that fear the stinging of wasps make fans of peacocks' tails, whose spots are like eyes", a clipping that reads "No woman knows what a bounder is. They can spot a barmaid by one glance at her nails but a man can bounce about the floor like a large ball and they can't see anything the matter with him", and a clipping that reads "she lay at rest in a bag of bones and water. The water poured out as the fisherman lifted it up, and the hag's head, with whisker-like barbels, looked out of the bass's mouth." Also included on the page is a black and white photograph of bare trees on a foggy day. Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

A black and white photograph of a snowy mountain top is pasted on the upper portion of the page, and an illustrated article from the "Animals in Legend" series of Zoo magazine titled "The Hydra" from 1937 is pasted onto the lower. On to the Zoo clipping, Morgan has pasted an additional small image that is sepia-toned and difficult to make out. In the center of a page and dividing the two larger clippings is a series of smaller text clippings, including a French language clipping from Ajalbert's Au Coeur de l'Auvergne, which reads "Laisse la tiède nuit t'envelopper; tu l'aimes,/ Et tu goùtes pensivement la volupté/ De recréer en toi son infini lacté,/ Lorsque sous tes paupières lasses qui la violent/ Tu la vois plus profonde et plus pleine d'étoiles/ Et cachant d'autres nuits sous cette profondeur", text by Haldrane that reads "bad barnacles when they die go to a rock where it is always low tide, while the virtuous are planted near the opening of an immense sewer, where food is carried to their mouths without any effort on their part", lines from a tire advert on blue paper describing "flexible ribs that wrinkle into squeegee-action", lines from Drayton's Nymphidia, which read "Upon a Grasshopper they got,/ And what with Amble, and with Trot,/ For hedge nor ditch they spared not,/ But after her they hie them", and three separate clippings arranged in a line that read "Touch the worm's skin", "(It can barely squeak and suckle)", and "Root, hog, or die". Along the top of the page, above the mountain clipping, there are two other text clippings, one reading "For the Lancaster Road is hard and long,/ But the road to the devil is sweet with song" and one describing the practice of shaving elephants with a blowtorch. Also included along the top of the page is a small black and white drawing of groups of men in the street. The men's dress appears Victorian.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodlessmall ink doodles
pages.desc: An illustrated clipping from Zoo magazine's "Animals in Legend" series titled "The Gorgon" takes up much of the page. The clipping recounts the appearances of Gorgons and Medusa in literature and legend. Other clippings on the page include a small black and white photograph of a relief carving showing a figure with a halo and a hand held up in benediction, a small black and white photograph that appears to depict pillars, surrounding it, lines from the The Merry Devil of Edmonton, reading "Jesus' daughter, Mary's child,/ Holy matron, woman mild,/ For thee a mass shall still be said,/ Every Sister drop a bead;/ And those again succeeding them/ For you shall sing a requiem", lines from Bale's God's Promises, reading "My heart abhorreth his willful misery,/ His cancred malice, his cursed covetousness,/ His lusts lecherous, his vengeable tyranny,/ Unmerciful murder and other ungodliness./ I will destroy him for his outrageousness,/ And not him only, but all that on earth do stir,/ For it repenteth me that ever I made them here", lines from Pepys's "Gaze not on Swans", reading "Gaze not on swans in whose soft breast/ A full-hatched beauty seems to nest,/ Nor snow which, falling from the sky, Hovers in its virginity", a clipping that reads "I looked at him, and by his expression I knew that the uproar of it all was now rushing through his mind, he was living again the indescribable", lines from "The Impatient Maid" verse from Peele's The Old Wives' Tale, reading "When as the rye reach to the chin,/ And chopcherry, chopcherry ripe within,/ Strawberries swimming in the cream,/ And school-boys playing in the stream;/ Then O, and then O, my true love said,/ Till that time come again,/ She could not live a maid", the line "I like not when a 'oman has a great peard: I spy a great peard under her muffler" from Shakespeare's The Merry Wives of Windsor, and a line that reads "I will go plain me to my lord the king". Below the Gorgon clipping, two black and white photographs of the doorways of churches are pasted in, as well a cropped black and white photograph of a young man, a black and white drawing of what looks to be trees, a black and white photograph of a snowy field, and a black and white photograph of a carved stone frieze. Also included on the lower part of the page is an excerpt from Mandeville's "The Lady of the Land", which reads "And some men say that in the Isle of Lango is yet the daughter of Hippocrates, in form and likeness of a great dragon, that is a hundred fathom of length, as men say: for I have not seen her", and Latin lines from Lucretius reading "cum pueri circum puerum pernice chorea armati in numerum pulsarent aeribus aera." Morgan has decorated the page with several blue and pink ink drawings.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodlessmall ink doodles
pages.desc: Two illustrated clippings from Zoo magazine's "Animals in Legend" series are centered down the middle of the page. The top clipping is titled "The Phoenix", which discusses the history of the Phoenix, and the lower clipping is titled "The Dragon", discussing both wingless and winged dragons in honour of St. George's day.  A small text-based clipping from "Willy Drowned in Yarrow", which read "'O came ye by yon water-side?/ Pou'd you the rose or lily?/ Or came you by yon meadow green,/ Or saw you my sweet Willie?" overlap onto the  Phoenix clipping. Surrounding these two clippings are smaller clippings, including a clipping describing a stork that was found frozen in ice in Luebeck, Germany and was revived, a Bulletin clipping titled "Blindfold Chess Player's Bid Succeeds", which discusses the Belgian chess master Georges Koltanowski, who played 34 opponents simultaneously in Edinburgh while blind-folded, a clipping reading "While scientists are continually waging war on insect pests, many species now adapt themselves to man's interference. The scale insect of California is now developing a strain that resists cyanide of strength to kill six men", a list of dog breeds from Berner's Boke of Seynt Albans, reading "A Grehoun, a Bastard, a Mengrel, a Mastiff, a Lemor, a Spanyll, Raaches, Kennetys, Teroures, Butchers Hounds, Dunghille Dogs, Tryndentaylles, Pryckeryd Currys and small ladyes' Poppees",  two excerpts from Greene's Friar Bacon and Friar Bungay reading "Therefore I charge thee by the immortal God,/ That holds the souls of men within his fist,/ This night thou watch" and "Conjuring and adjuring devils and fiends,/ With stole and alb and strange penageron;/ The wresting of the holy name of God,/ As Soter, Eloim, and Adonai,/ Alpha, Manoth, and Tetragrammaton," a clipping discussing  the use of the Slender Loris in "love-charms and philtres" and Sir Emerson Tennent's report that "they hold the little animal to the fire till the eye-balls burst",  an article titled "Language Mystery", which describes an Australian boy of 5 who cannot speak his own language but speaks fluent Italian, and an article on the fertility of nature discussed through the breeding capacities of the bacillus and oysters. A small clipping of hieroglyphs, a black and white photograph of a stone relief carving of a man, which is a detail from a larger work, and a colour photograph of a green and yellow beetle are also included. Pink and blue ink doodles by Morgan decorate the page.

pages.notes: small pink ink doodles
pages.desc: A large sepia-toned reproduction of a painting of a tiger dominates the center of the page. The clipping is turned to the landscape orientation. The facing page, page 222, which contains an associated clipping, describes the painting as Gaho Hashimoto's painting on a folding screen, and indicates that the painting was reproduced as part of an article titled "Japan's Year of the Tiger". Small text-based clippings surround the tiger painting. These include an excerpt from an article by Campbell which describes the planet Mercury, stating "Whatever frightful contortions of utterly dark, jagged rock the frozen dark side may exhibit, unweathered by windblown sand where there is not win, unworn by rain where there has been no water in a thousand million years, uncracked by repeated frost, since frost there is not repeated, but a thing enduring all time, we can guess what the Sunward side looks like", two excerpts from Peele's The Old Wife's Tale, the first reading "Head. Gently dip, but not too deep,/ For fear you make the golden beard to weep./ Fair maiden, white and red,/ Comb me smooth, and stroke my head,/ And thou shalt have some cockle-bread", and the second reading "2nd Head. Gently dip, but not too deep,/ For fear thou make the golden beard to weep./ Fair maid, white and red,/ Comb me smooth, and stroke my head,/ And every hair a sheaf shall be,/ And every sheaf a golden tree". Other clippings include Bertran de Born's lament, reading "elh plor elh marrimen", lines from Poe's "The City in the Sea", which read "But light from out the lurid sea / Streams up the turrets silently -", lines from Thomas's "The Trees", which read  "There was the blood of the noon sun on the trunk of the elder, staining the bark", Hemingway's description of marlin fishing, the opening line from Rictus's "Elegie", which reads "Quand la nuit verse sa tristesse au firmament", lines from Milton's "The Doctrine and Discipline of Divorce", reading "Who shall answer for the perishing of all those souls perishing by stubborn expositions of particular and inferior precepts against the generall and supreme rule of charity?", the names of dwarfs listed in "The Poetic Edda", two clippings from Kyd's The Spanish Tragedy, one reading "Thou talk'st of harvest, when the corn is green:/ The end is crown of every work well done;/ The sickle comes not, till the corn be ripe" and the other reading "Ergo tuos oculos nunquam, mea vita, videbo,/ Et tua perpetuus sepelivit lumina somnus?/ Emoriar tecum: sic, sic juvat ire sub umbras", lines possibly from Pound's "Night Litany" reading "Purifiez nos coeurs/ Purifiez nos coeurs", and a clipping that reads "'Whale!' he cried, sitting straight up in bed." One larger clipping discusses  the work of colour scientists in the Du Pont de Nemours & Co technical laboratory and states that much colour matching is done by humans, due to the ability of the human eye to detect approximately 100,000 different hues. Another small clipping reads "My lover is but a small man, / So would I have him be;/ Fewer leaves and more fruit ever / We find on the little tree". A black and white drawing of a mole and a small black and white photograph of a stone carving are also included. Morgan has added small pink ink doodles, and a small handwritten note appears on the page below the large clipping of the tiger and above the colour research clipping, reading "dretching of swevens".

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: An illustrated, sepia-toned black and white article, titled "Japan's Year of the Tiger" from Zoo magazine is pasted in the center of the page. This clipping is an associated clipping with the Tiger painting shown on page 221. On the left and right side of the article clipping, three black and white photographs of flowers, two black and white photographs of sea anemones, and one colour photograph of a butterfly are included. Along the top and bottom of the page are small text clippings, including lines from Peele's The Love of King David and Fair Bethsabe, With the Tragedy of Absalon, which read "God in the whizzing of a pleasant wind, Shall march upon the tops of mulberry-trees", the opening lines from MacNeice's "Upon This Beach", reading "Upon this beach the falling wall of the sea / Explodes its drunken marble/ Amid gulls' gaiety", lines by Francis Carco, reading "De sentir, dans ton âme et ta chair confondues,/ Vibrer le paysage et brûler la saison", lines by Du Bartas, reading "Ainsi que les corbeaux d'vne penne venteuse/ Passans les bois pleurans de l'Arabie heureuse,/ Mesprisent les iardins et parcs delicieux,/ Qui de fleurs esmaillez vont parfumant les cieux/ Et s'arrestent, gloutons, sur la sale carcasse", and lines from Thomas Kyd's The Spanish Tragedy, reading "Eyes, life, world, heav'ns, hell, night, and day,/ See, search, shew, send some man, some mean, that may-". Also included is a Henri Bergson quotation, reading " We think with only a small part of the past, but it is with our entire past, including the original bent of our soul, that we desire, will, and act". The page is decorated with blue and pink ink drawings.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: This page is taken up almost wholly by excerpts from an article discussing scientific research into ageing, with particular attention paid to the various physical and cellular adaptations that plants, animals, and microorganisms can make in response to their environment. The clipped excerpts continue onto the next page (page 224). In between the excerpted clippings, Morgan has inserted small lines of text that can be seen as commenting on the article to some extent. The first is from Poe's "The City in the Sea" and reads "The viol, the violet, and the vine", appearing before the section that discusses plants. The second is from Desbordes-Valmore's poem "Les roses de Saâdi" and reads "J'ai voulu ce matin te rapporter des roses" appearing after a section on regeneration. A final line is from Middleton's Women Beware Women and reads "Lust and forgetfulness have been amongst us . . .", appearing after a discussion of a dog born without fore-legs that learned to hop, and consequently led to alterations in the proportions of its skeleton. The article includes one small diagram of a Planarian worm, and Morgan has drawn some small pink and blue ink doodles, but otherwise, this page lacks images.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink drawings, including a little drawing of a spider
pages.desc: Continuation of the article from page 223 dealing with scientific research into regeneration and other adaptations that animals and microorganisms are capable of. Morgan has included five clipped diagrams from the article, as well as two sections of text on this page. Scattered around the page are other small excerpts of text, including a line reading "It's strictly screwball/ business from Z to A, with a headache and a / heartache for every foot of the assembly line", a French line reading "n'est. rose. sans. epine", a Latin line reading "Memento homo quod cinis es, et in cinerem reverteris", lines From Heywood's A Woman Killed with Kindness, which reads "O God! O God! that it were possible / To undo things done; to call back yesterday. . . .", lines from Thomas Middleton and William Rowley's tragedy The Changeling, reading "Can you weep Fate from its determined purpose? So soon many you weep me", a line from Kyd's The Spanish Tragedy reading "For here though death hath end their misery / I'll there begin their endless tragedy", lines from Tennyson's Lancelot and Elaine reading "And up in Agned-Cathregonion too,/ And down the waste sand-shores of Trath Treroit", the line "His heart stabb'd in with knife is reft of life" from Sackville and Norton's Gorboduc, the line "a gloomy weight of guns" from Ruskin's "Our Marine Architecture", Latin line from Cicero, which reads "tu quoque, cum tumulos Albano in monte niualis/ lustrasti et laeto mactasti lacte Latinas,/ uidisti et claro tremulos ardore cometas;"and the line "Resignedly beneath the sky / The melancholy waters lie" from Poe's "The City in the Sea". As with page 223, many of these textual excerpts can be read as a comment on the science being discussed in the article. Other clippings include the Old English lines "Wēa bid sundrum clibbor. Wolcnu scridad" from Maxims II, lines reading "swinging a long thing juniper log from whose charred end arose a filmy smoke. A delicious incense pervaded", lines reading "All the whiles that I may my bow bend/ Shall I wed no wife./ I shall bigge me a bower at the wood's end/ There to lead my life", reading a clipping that looks to be in Greek, a colour photograph of a black and yellow spider, and a colour photograph of a blue-green iridescent beetle with black spots. Morgan has included small pink and blue ink doodles, including a doodle of a spider.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink drawings
pages.desc: A black and white drawing of a jellyfish among seaweed takes up the center of the page. Morgan has labelled the illustration as being from Zoo magazine's Animals in Art series. Various clippings are pasted around this Zoo clipping, including a colour photograph of a blue and green beetle, a black and white photograph of a metallic figure that may be a hippogriff, a small black and white photograph of what looks to be the torso and hand of a statue, which includes a book in the statue's hand, a small black and white photograph of a decorative stone carving, and a black and white photograph of a loch surrounded by hills, possibly at sunset. Text-based clippings include lines from Tennyson's "The Princess: Now Sleeps the Crimson Petal", which read "'Now lies the Earth all Danaë to the stars,/ And all thy heart lies open unto me", a clipping from Langewiesche's I'll Take the High Road that describes the feeling of floating under a parachute as "dreamlike" and "like flying in dreams, flying simply because you are light", an anonymous inscription reading "Grass of levity,/ Span in brevity,/ Flowers' felicity,/ Fire of misery,/ Winds' stability,/ Is mortality", a Scottish child's grace reading "Madam Poussie's coming hame, / Riding on a gray stane. / What's to the supper?/ Pease, brose and butter./ Wha'll say the grace?/ I'll say the grace-/ Leviticus, Levaticus,/ Taste, taste, taste", two clippings from Massinger's The Virgin Martyr, one describing Bacchus, "the god of brew'd wine and sugar", and the one reading "Hir. I'll come upon her with rounce, robble-hobble, and thwick-thwack-thirlery bouncing", lines from Poe's "The Bells", reading "They are neither man nor woman - / They are neither brute nor human -", the opening line from Rowley's "An Excelente Balade of Charitie", reading "In Virgine the sweltry sun 'gan sheene", an excerpt from Lois Mattox Miller's Hygeia, which reads "We convey the virus in a handshake or a kiss, or we leave it on the doorknob", the line "And on the mere the wailing died away" from Tennyson's Morte d'Arthur, a Latin clipping from Bernard of Cluny's De Contemptu mundi, reading "Denique montibus altior omnibus ultimus ignis/ Surget, inertibus ima tenentibus, astra benignis,/ Flammaque libera surget ad aëra, surget ad astra,/ Diruet atria, moenia, regna, suburbia, castra", lines from Poe's poem "Israfel", reading "*And the angel Israfel, whose heartstrings are a lute, and who has the sweetest voice of all God's creatures.-", lines from Lear's "The Daddy Long-Legs and the Fly", reading "They sailed across the silent main,/ And reached the great Gromboolian plain/ And there they play for evermore/ At battlecock and shuttledore", lines regarding Lilith from Shaw's Back to Methuselah, reading "Of Life only is there no end; and though of its million starry mansions many are empty and many still unbuilt, and though its vast domain is as yet unbearably desert, my seed shall one day fill it and master its matter to its uttermost confines. And for what may be beyond, the eyesight of Lilith is too short. It is enough that there is a beyond", the full text of Lear's "There Was a Young Lady of Parma", lines from Tennyson's Maud, reading "The red rose cries, 'She is near, she is near;'/ And the white rose weeps, 'She is late;'/ The larkspur listens, 'I hear, I hear;'/ And the lily whispers, 'I wait", lines from Poe's "The Sleeper", reading "I pray to God that she may lie/ For ever with unopened eye,/ While the dim sheeted ghosts go by", a paragraph from Swedenborg's Heaven and Hell, reading "414. They who are in heaven are continually advancing to the spring-time of life, and the more thousands of years they live, the more delightful and happy is the spring to which they attain, and this to eternity, with an increase according to the progressions and degrees of their love, charity, and faith", and lines from Hopkin's "The Sea and the Skylark", reading " On ear and ear two noises too old to end/ Trench-right, the tide that ramps against the shore;/ With a flood or a fall, low lull-off or all roar,/ Frequenting there while moon shall wear and wend./ Left hand, off land, I hear the lark ascend,/ His rash-fresh re-winded new-skeinèd score/ In crisps of curl off wild winch whirl, and pour/ And pelt music, till none's to spill or spend".  Morgan has also clipped a monogram with a brief caption that says the monogram contains "all the letters of the alphabet". Morgan has decorated the page with pink and blue ink doodles.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: Two black and white and one sepia-toned image fill the center of this page. The top image is a black and white photograph of Paul Klee's 1935 painting "Ball and Doll". The middle image is a black and white photograph of a carved casket, captioned "English Whalebone Casket. Left Side. c. 7th Century", which Morgan has annotated as "Frank's Casket" in blue ink. The bottom image is a sepia-toned photograph of a painting of a cheetah, on which Morgan has written "(PISANELLO)" to identify the artist. The only other image on the page is a small black and white photograph of a decorative carved human figure, likely clipped from a larger image. The rest of the clippings are text-based. These include the opening lines of Coventry Carol, which read "Lully, lulla, thou little tiny child,/ By by, lully lullay", lines from Tennyson's "Tithonus", which reads "Man comes and tills the earth and lies beneath/ And after many a summer dies the swan", a 25-word story about the shadow of a clock wearing a hole in the back of the clock casing (this story was a 1934 winner of the Liar's Club competition), lines from Coleridge's Christabel, reading "A little child, a limber elf,/ Singing, dancing to itself,/ A fairy thing with red round cheeks/ That always finds, and never seeks", a clipping reading "Owing to a strike of bakers, the town was entirely beadles for the day", lines from Henry Williamson's Salar the Salmon, reading "The spate rose rapidly, and washed all away, to the sea which gives absolution, alike to the living and the dead", lines from Lear's "The Pelican Chorus" reading "Ploffskin, Pluffskin, Pelican jee,/ We think no Birds so happy as we!/ Plumpskin, Ploshkin, Pelican jill,/ We think so then, and we thought so still!", a clipping reading "'How does a porcelain cup come into this matter?' asked Lord Bowglie dreamily", a description from Swedenborg's Heaven and Hell of unnamed, dreadful beings who faces can be "like those of corpses", "black", "fiery like little torches", "disfigured with pimples, warts, and large ulcers", or, "with some, no face appears, but in its stead something hairy or bony; and with some teeth only are seen", lines from Donne's "An Epithalamion, or Marriage Song on the Lady Elizabeth, and Count Palatine being married on St Valentines Day", which read "The Lirique Larke, and the grave whispering Dove", lines from Malory's Le Morte d'Arthur describing a "black launde" wherein every feature described is black, lines from Donne's "Death's Duel", which begin "This death of incineration and dispersion is, to natural reason, the most irrecoverable death of all" and yet continue to discuss the "blessed and glorious resurrection" promised by God, lines from Lear's "There was an Old Man of the Nile", which read "There was an Old Man of the Nile/ Who sharpened his nails with a file,/ Till he cut off his thumbs,/ And said calmly, 'This comes/ Of sharpening one's nails with a file!", and the line "The sharpë, greenë, sweetë Junipere" written by James I of Scotland. Two other clippings appear to be in Old English. Small pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: Two clippings from Zoo magazine's "Animals in Art" series take up most of the page. Both include sepia-tone photographs. The top clipping is from 1957 and titled "The Old Chinese". It shows monkeys, beavers, deer, lion, and giraffe in various forms of Chinese art. Morgan has pasted a small black and white photograph of a medallion in the upper right corner of this clipping and a small black and white photograph of a house from the outside overlaps with the upper left corner of the Zoo clipping. The lower clipping is from 1936 and is titled "3- The Old Chinese". It shows a "rendering of a dog in pottery" and "a bronze wine vessel in the form of an owl". Morgan has pasted three additional images onto this larger clipping: a black and white photograph of a porcelain figurine, a black and white reproduction of a painting showing a woman on a horse riding sidesaddle, and a black and white photograph of a medallion. The right side of the lower clipping has been folded over to fit the page, and on the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted three black and white images: a photograph of a marble statue of a human figure in a courtyard, a black and white photograph of a metallic basket, and a black and white photograph of a porcelain figurine of woman in a gown who is holding a mask in one hand. Text-based clippings include a verse from Whitman's "There was a Child went Forth" that reads, "There was a child went forth every day, / And the first object he look'd upon, that object he / became,/ And that object became part of him for the day or / a certain part of the day. / Or for many years or stretching cycles of years", a clipping from Marlowe's Doctor Faustus, which reads "Think'st thou that I, who saw the face of God,/ And tasted the eternal joys of heaven,/ Am not tormented with ten thousand hells,/ In being depriv'd of everlasting bliss?", lines from Dunbar's "The Dance", which read "Mony sweir bumbard belly huddron", a joke about adders on Noah's ark who can't "go forth and multiply", lines from Thomas's "The Mouse and the Woman" reading "One day I may have no limbs to walk with, no hands to touch with. No heart under my breast", a line from Chapman and Marlowe's Hero and Leander, which reads "Joy graven in sense, like snow in water, wasts", lines from Kyd's The Spanish Tragedy, which read "You have oft, for these two lips,/ Neglected cassia, or the natural sweets/ Of the spring-violet: they are not yet much wither'd", and lines from Thomas's "A Saint About to Fall", which read "Cry joy that this witchlike midwife second / Bullies into rough seas you so gentle/ And makes with a flick of the thumb and sun/ A thundering bullring of your silent and girl-circled/ island". Three text-based clippings on this page are arranged almost like lines of poetry: a line from a German hymn reading "Wir weren all verloren", a line from Webster's The Duchess of Malfi reading "a face folded in sorrow", and a line reading "the usual cafuffle". Morgan has decorated the page with pink and blue ink doodle.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: Clippings from Zoo magazine's "Animals in Art" series are the focus of this page. The two included installments focus on animal sculptures. One clipping, dated Nov 1936, discusses and includes photographs of a sculpture titled "The Running Boar" by Pompon and a sculpture titled "The Playing Bear Cubs" by Anders Jonsson. The other installment, dated June 1936, shows three sculptures, one of which is titled "A Duck", one titled "Charging Bull", and one titled "Saddled Horse", all by John Skeaping. Other clippings on the page include a small black and white photograph of a glossy looking male figure (possibly porcelain), a small black and white photograph of a stone statue, a black and white photograph that is difficult to make out but appears to show some sort of circular pattern, a black and white photograph of an outdoor sculpture (possibly of a buffalo) covered in a layer of snow, a black and white photograph of a small clock, and pasted into the corner of the running boar photograph, Morgan has included a photograph of himself as a baby in 1921. Next to this baby photo, Morgan has pasted a short poem, reading "Hey Diddle Diddle / Humpty, Dumpty/ Twinkle, Twinkle / Ding, Dong, Bell". Elsewhere on the page is a clipping that describes a fight between a dragon and a boar from Malory's Le Morte D'arthur, a clipping titled "The Sleeping Dragon of Snowdon (Caernarvonshire)" that describes Merlin's discovery of two sleeping dragons beneath the land where chief Vortigern was attempting to build a castle, a clipping, titled "The Lambton Worm (Durham)", which describes a great worm that the heir of Lambton allowed to live when he discovered that the only way to kill it would be to kill his own father. For this failure to act, the heir suffers a sibyl's curse. Another clipping, titled "King Oswald's Arm (Bamborough, Yorkshire)", describes King Oswald's generosity to beggars at an Easter feast, and a subsequent blessing prayed on the "arm which performed the deed" by Bishop Aidan. Although Oswald was killed in battle, his arm is said not to have decayed in 900 years. Other clippings include a Latin clipping from Lucretius, which read "E tenebris tantis tam clarum extollere lumen qui primus potuisti inlustrans commode uitae, te sequor", lines from Wylie's poem "The Eagle and the Mole", which read "If you would keep your soul/ From spotted sight or sound,/ Live like the velvet mole;/ Go burrow underground./ And there hold intercourse/ With roots of trees and stones,/ With rivers at their source,/ And disembodied bones", lines from Fletcher's "Christ's Victory and Triumph", reading "Had I a voice of steel to tune my song,/ Were every verse as smoothly fil'd as glasse,/ And every member turned to a tongue,/ And every tongue were made of sounding brasse", and Anglo-Saxon lines from the poem "The Phoenix", reading "ne lifes lyre ne lapes cyme,/ ne synn ne sacu, ne sār wracu,/ ne aaedle gewinn ne welan onsyn,/ ne sorg ne slaep, ne swār leger,/ ne wintergeweorp, ne wedra gebregd/ hrēoh under heofonum, ne se hearda forst/ caldum cylegicelum cnysed aenigne". Morgan has decorated the page with pink and blue ink doodles.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles, including an elvish doodle to go with a clipping
pages.desc: Two clippings from Zoo magazine's Animals in Art series are centered on this page, both of which focus on church carvings and sculptures. The first clipping is from 1937 and shows German church carvings, one of an owl and one of two lemurs playing chess. The second clipping is from 1938 and is titled "Animals in Art: More Old English Church Carvings". One picture shows Noah's ark and the other is captioned as "Hare and Hound - or Perturbation and Desolation?". Surrounding the clippings are various image- and text-based clippings. Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a relief bust of Rousseau, a Reader's Digest clipping quoting the N.Y. Herald Tribune and discussing how a man in Harlem invented a new word on New Year's Eve (Hallalouyear!), which was in use across the city by morning, a black and white photograph of a second relief bust carving, and a colour photograph of a green and red beetle. A Brittania clipping, titled "The Holy Head of Halifax (Yorkshire)" describes how Father Aeldred lost his reason and mistook a beautiful probationer as a temptation from the Devil, killing her before fleeing to the hills to die himself. The woman's beauty is described as "elfin" and above this clipping, Morgan has drawn pointed blue elf ears and pink eyes. Other clippings include lines from Burns's "How Long and Dreary is the Night", which read "When I think on the happy days/ I spent wi' you, my dearie;/ And now what lands between us lie,/ How can I be but eerie!/ How slow ye move, ye heavy hours,/ As ye were wae and weary!/ It was na sae ye glinted by/ When I was wi' my dearie", lines from Drummond's "Inexorable" reading "My thoughts hold mortal strife;/ I do detest my life,/ And with lamenting cries,/ Peace to my soul to bring/ Oft call that prince which here doth monarchize:/ --But he, grim grinning King,/ Who caitiffs scorns, and doth the blest surprise,/ Late having deck'd with beauty's rose his tomb,/ Disdains to crop a weed, and will not come" , a clipping stating that French scientists Rene Bernard and Degardin have posited that the sky is salt, and that the whole universe may be as well, a clipping that lists several chemical compounds, lines from Boyer's story "Colour Nut" which read "He solemnly assured them that the step would once more be firm, the eye bright if they only placed themselves in his hands", lines from Ford's 'Tis Pity She's a Whore reading "Oh, Vasques, Vasques, in this piece of flesh,/ This faithless face of hers, had I laid up/ The treasure of my heart", two clippings with lines from Marlowe's Tamburlaine the Great, one reading "With milk-white harts upon an ivory sled/ Thou shalt be drawn amidst the frozen pools" and the other reading "One thought, one grace, one wonder, at the least/ Which into words no virtue can digest", lines from Spenser's The Faerie Queene reading "So forth they rowed, and that Ferryman/ With his stiffe oares did brush the sea so strong,/ That the hoare waters from his frigot ran,/ And the light bubbles daunced all along,/ Whiles the salt brine out of the billowes sprong", two clippings with lines from Webster's The Duchess of Malfi , one reading "Thou art a box of worm-seed, at best but a salvatory of green mummy. What's this flesh? a little crudded milk, fantastical puff-paste" and the other reading "Cover her face; mine eyes dazzle: she died young", a line from Donne's "Elegie on Mistress Boulstred" reading "O Strong and long-liv'd death, how cam'st thou in?", lines from Thomas's "There was a Saviour" reading "There was a saviour/ Rarer than radium,/ Commoner than water, crueler than truth", and a small black and white photograph of an ornate clock. Morgan has decorated the page in pink and blue ink drawings.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles, commentary by Morgan on two of the clippings
pages.desc: This page has several large images. The first is a black and white photograph of a fresco of Jesus resurrected, next to which is a black and white photograph of an enamel medallion with the caption "Jean Fouquet: Portrait de l'artiste (vers 1450)". Morgan has added some annotations to this medallion clipping. He has written "(supposed)" above the assertion that is a self-portrait and has added notes reading "Enamel Medallion (Louvre)" and another "NB: the eyes are lighter then appears in this reproduction; the expression even more perplexed & farseeing. EM". Below these clippings is a black and white photograph of a night sky and a crater-covered landscape (possibly a rendering of the moon?), as well as a black and white photograph of what Morgan notes as "noctiluca" (Noctilucales). In the lower left of the page is a black and white newspaper photograph of a bird, captioned as "One of Nature's Freaks - This Fairy Swallow, with wings growing from its feet, was caught at Lumphanan, Aberdeenshire. It is now tame, and when on view soon draws a crowd." This page also includes four Brittanica clippings. "The Devil's Arrows (Aldborough, Yorkshire)" tells of a debate between Christian and Druid beliefs in which a devil disguised himself and began to sway favour away from the Christian until it was seen that his feet were melting the rock he stood on. "The White Hare (Cornwall)" discusses the belief that broken-hearted maidens reappear after death as white hares. "The Glastonbury Thorn (Glastonbury, Somerset)" describes the great fecundity of a tree that grew from Joseph of Arimathea's hawthorn staff. "The Dancers of Stanton Drew (Somerset)" tells of a bride who refused to stop dancing on her wedding night, even when warned that the party had extended into the Lord's Day. A fiddler arrived who played through the night, but soon the party found they could not stop dancing. In the morning, the revelers were gone and groups of stones were in their place. Other clippings include a large excerpt from Wordsworth's "The Simplon Pass", beginning with the lines "The immeasurable height/ Of woods decaying, never to be decayed" and ending with "Characters of the great Apocalypse,/ The types and symbols of Eternity,/ Of first, and last, and midst, and without/ end", two clippings with lines from Spenser's The Faerie Queene, one reading "And all within the riuen walls were hung/ With ragged monuments of times forepast/ All which the sad effects of discord sung:" and the other reading "The great earthes wombe they open to the sky", lines from Webster's The White Devil reading "Thou hast led me, like an heathen sacrifice,/ With music, and with fatal yokes of flowers", lines that read "Far fragrant orchards flinging slaking fruit,/ Where syrups press upon the weeping feet", and a clipping of Chinese characters that shows the combination of characters used to make certain words. One of these shows that Peace combines the character for Roof and Woman, under which Morgan has written "Soloman!". Another clipping describes supplies for a large feast, including "500 pints of clear mock turtle soup", "230 roast chickens" and "12 dozen bottles of beer, and red and white wine". Another clipping says that 76-year-old John Frederick Cotty was found "unfit to plead to a charge of murdering his wife, Amy Blanche Cotty (78)" and so was detained "during His Majesty's pleasure". Image-based clippings on the page include two clippings that show decorative relief carvings, a small black and white image that is difficult to make out, a black and white photograph of what appear to be carvings of lions, a black and white photograph of a medallion with a horse's head cut out in the center, and a black and white photograph of three worms or larvae, as well as pink and blue ink doodles, decorate the page.

This page is dominated by a large clipping from Zoo magazine showing four black and white photographs. The top image is a photograph of a relief scene on a grave that depicts "Farmers with geese and cranes". The second image is a photograph of a "Decorative relief of a hare, from a tomb of about 3,000 B.C.". The third image is a photograph of a "tomb sculpture of an ichneumon climbing a branch to rob a bird's nest". The last image is a photograph of a wall painting from the tomb of Nebamun, which shows Nebamun hunting birds in the Nile marshes (dated around 1350 BC). This clipping is large and its inside right edge has been folded over to make it fit into the book. On the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted five other clippings. One is a black and white photograph what Morgan has annotated as being a Feather Box from New Zealand, one is an unclear black and white image, probably excerpted from a larger image, one is a clipping titled "Frog, Toad, and Fish" that describes the author's discovery of a toad embracing a female frog, which reminds the author of having seen a frog embracing a goldfish before, one clipping is a black and white photograph of a bat with its wings folded, and the final clipping is a black and white photograph of a rock formation. The page contains only three other clippings. The first is a small verse from MacLeish's "You, Andrew Marvell", reading "And here face down beneath the sun,/ And here upon the earth's noonward height/ To feel the always coming on,/ The always rising of the night", the second is a long Latin clipping from Lucretius, beginning "aureaque Hesperidum seruans fulgentia mala" and ending with "cum bene praesertim multa ac diuinitus ipsis/ immortalibu' de diuis dare dicta suerit/ atque omnem rereum naturam pandere dictis", and the last is two verses from Eliot's "Sweeney among the Nightingales", reading "The host with someone indistinct/ Converses at the door apart,/ The nightingales are singing near/ The Convent of the Sacred Heart,/ And sang within the bloody wood/ When Agamemnon cried aloud,/ And let their liquid siftings fall,/ To stain the stiff dishonoured shroud."

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: This page contains four large black and white images. The first is a photograph of a carved fragment from the Easby Cross showing a bird and a horse figure. The second is a photograph of a stone carving titled "Creation", which shows two figures being formed out of the earth. On top of this clipping, Morgan has pasted a small verse, reading "From Man / Came Woman / From Woman / Came Sin / From Sin / Came Death". Below this clipping, Morgan has included a small black and white photograph of a section of a stone relief carving showing figures on horseback, as well as a verse from Donne's "Elegy on the Lady Markham", which reads "In her this sea of death hath made no breach, / But as the tide doth wash the slimie beach, / And leaves embroder'd workes upon the sand / So is her flesh refin'd by deaths cold hand". Along the right side of the Creation clipping, Morgan has included a short line of text from Spenser's The Faerie Queene reading "Death is the end of woes: die soone, O faeries / sonne" and a black and white photograph of an ornate clock face. The third clipping is a photograph of a stone statue of the Virgin Mary, which Morgan has labelled "Virgin: Westminster: C13". Along the left side of this image, Morgan has included a small black and white photograph of a crucifix, as well as three text clippings, including lines from the poem "My Truest Treasure", which read "My dearworthy darling, so dolefully dight,/ Sa straitly up-right, strained on the rood;/ For Thy mickle meekness, Thy mercy, Thy might,/ Thou bete all my bales with bote of Thy blood", the lines "But direfull deadly blacke both leafe and bloom/ Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery / toombe" from The Faerie Queene, and a single line that reads "He confessed to being no orator, but was nevertheless brief." The final of the four main images is a black and white photograph of a figure embossed on a silver plate, which Morgan's annotation dates as "before 867". Blue and pink ink drawings decorate the page.

pages.notes: small pink and blue ink doodles, including one that resembles a fish
pages.desc: A large black and white reproduction of El Greco's "La Obra Representa la Inmaculada Concepción de la Virgen María" is in the centre of the page. Other clippings on this page include a black and white photograph of carved lion on top of a relief carving, a small black and white newspaper photograph of a man onto which Morgan has written the initials "F.S.", a black and white photograph that seems to show decorative pieces of glass, and a black and white photograph of statue with a crown and ceremonial clothing. Text-based clippings on the page include lines from Chaucer, reading "Why lyked me thy yellow heer to see/ More than the boundes of myn honestee,/ Why lyked me thy youthe and thy fairnesse,/ And of thy tonge the infinit graciousnesse?", two clippings in French, one reading "Et le gosse, écrasant son nez à la fenêtre,/ Pâle d'enthousiasme et le Coeur oppressé,/ Écarquille ses yeux fiévreux et réve d'être/ Le fiancé/ De la très delicate et très mignonne reine/ Que craque dans la soie ardente et les bijoux/ Et que suit comme un page, en soulevant sa traîne,/ Un sapajou," and the other, which is a handwritten clipping quoting from the essays of Montaigne, reading "S'il se pouvoit dresser une telle accointance, libre et volontaire, où, nor seulemnet les ames eussent cette entiene jouyssance, mais encores où les corps eussent pait a l'alliance, où l'homme fuest engage tout entire: il est certain que l'amitié eu seroit plus pleine et plus comble", a Latin clipping from Pervigilium Veneris, reading "adsonat Terei puella subter ubmram populi,/ ut putes motus amoris ore dici musico/ et neges queri sororem de marito barbaro./ illa cantat : nos tacemus ? quando uer ueniet meum ?/ quando fiam uti chelidon ut tacere desinam ?/ perdidi Musam tacendo nec me Phoebus respicit./ sic Amyclas cum tacerent perdidit silentium./ cras amet qui numquam amauit quique amauit cras amet ! ", lines from Clough's "Claude to Eustace" poem reading "Tibur is beautifu too, and the orchard slopes, and the Anio/ Falling, falling yet, to the ancient lyrical cadence;/ Tibur and Anio's stride", lines from John Donne's "The Anniversary", reading "Only our love hath no decay;/ This, no to morrow hath, nor yesterday,/ Running it never runs from us away,/ But truly keepes his first, last, everlasting day", lines from Dylan Thomas's "And Death Shall Have No Dominion", reading "Though they go mad they shall be sane,/ Though they sink through the sea they shall rise again;/ Though lovers be lost love shall not;/ And death shall have no dominion", lines from Wordsworth's The Prelude, reading "when the light of sense/ Goes out, but with a flash that has revealed/ The invisible world, doth greatness make abode,/ There harbours; whether we be young or old,/ Our destiny, our being's heart and home,/ Is with infinitude, and only there;/ With hope it is, hope that can never die,/ Effort, and expectation, and desire,/ And with something evermore about to be", two clippings with lines from Milton's Paradise Lost, one reading "Thus what thou desir'st,/ And what thou fearst, alike destroyes all hope/ Of refuge, and concludes thee miserable/ Beyond all past example and future,/ To Satan onely like both crime and doom./ O Conscience, into what Abyss of fears/ And horrors hast thou driv'n me; out of which/ I find no way, from deep to deeper plung'd!" and the other reading "neer that bituminous Lake where Sodam flam'd", lines from Thomas's "The Mill-Pond", reading "Less than the cooing in the alder/ Isles of the pool/ Sounded the thunder through that plunge/ Of waters cool", lines from Walter de la Mare's "Fare Well", reading "Look thy last on all things lovely,/ Every hour. Let no night/ Seal thy sense in deathly slumber/ Till to delight/ Thou have paid thy utmost blessing;/ Since that all things thou wouldst praise/ Beauty took from those who loved them/ In other days", and a clipping that may be in Old English. Many of these clippings discuss love and/or beauty that can survive death, although one clipping, from Henry King's "Exequy on his Wife", laments the loss of his wife and reads "But thou wilt never more appear/ Folded within my Hemisphear,/ Since both thy light and motion/ Like a fled Star is fall'n and gon,/ And twixt me and my soules dear wish/ The earth now interposed is,/ Which such a strange eclipse doth make/ As ne'er was read in Almanake". One blue and two pink ink doodles, one of which resembles a fish, also decorate the page.

This page is roughly divided into three sections. A large black and white photograph of the sun shining brightly through dark clouds over a flat prairie scene takes up the top part of this page. The middle of the page is comprised of a black and white photograph of a field of daisies on the left. On the right, three sections of text are included: the line "Eftsoones they heard a most melodious sound" from Spenser's The Fairy Queene, four verses with a focus on singing from Thomas Campion's "Laura", which read "Rose-cheeked Laura, come;/ Sing thou smoothly with thy beauty's/ Silent music, either other/ Sweetly gracing./ Lovely forms do flow/ From concent divinely framed;/ Heaven is music, and thy beauty's/ Birth is heavenly./ These dull notes we sing/ Discords need for helps to grace them,/ Only beauty purely loving/ Knows no discord,/ But still moves delight,/ Like clear springs renewed by flowing,/ Ever perfect, ever in them-/ selves eternal",  and the lines "And lovely laughter leaps and falls / Upon their lips in madrigals" from Stevenson's "In the Season". The bottom of the page is taken up by a large aerial black and white photograph of a mountain range.

This page is taken up largely by a black and white clipping that shows nine captioned photographs of various diatoms in a grid pattern. One of these diatoms is called Echinus, and beside the caption, Morgan has written "(sea-urchin)".  Above this large clipping are two black and white photographs of seashells, as well as a clipped line of text that reads "Orlando the Marmalade Cat". Along the right side of the clipping are two verses of poetry, one from Traherne's poem "Dumbness", reading "This, my dear friends, this was my blessed case;/ For nothing spoke to me but the fair face/ Of Heaven and Earth, before myself could speak,/ I then my Bliss did, when my silence, break", and one from Donne's "The Anniversary", reading "True and False feares let us refraine,/ Let us love nobly, and live, and adde againe/ Yeares and yeares unto yeares, till we attaine/ To write threescore: this is the second of our raigne". Also included is a text excerpt that reads "lives in Campden Hill, within a stone's throw of Charles Morgan, but says 'I've never thrown a stone at him.'" Below the large clipping is a handwritten text excerpt that is not written in modern English (possibly Old English), a line from a letter to T.W from Donne, reading "My verse, the strict Map of my misery", and lines from Davies' short story "The Wages of Love", reading "The rusty mountains wept, the bobbing chrysanthemums in the back-gardens were running with liquid coal-dust. A wind whipped through the dirty valey and rubbed stingingly at her silken legs". To the left of the large clipping is a line of verse from the anonymous poem "The Seven Virgins: A Carol", which reads "Oh the rose, the rose, the gentle rose,/ And the fennel that grows so green!".

pages.notes: small pink ink doodle
pages.desc: The center of the page is taken up by an illustrated clipping that focuses on the art of Albrecht Dürer from Zoo magazine's "Animals in Art" series. The clipping shows drawings of a crab, a young hare, and a stag-beetle. On the larger clipping, near the title, Morgan has pasted a small triangular clipping showing decorative flowers in black and white. He has drawn a similarly sized triangle in pink ink on the other side of the larger clipping's title as well.  Variously pasted around the larger clipping are three images: a black and white photograph of a decorative vase, a small black and white photograph of a carved hooded figure, and a black and white photograph of a ceramic male figure. There are also several excerpts of poetry and short sections of prose framing the larger clipping, including lines from Poe's "Israfel", reading "If I could dwell/ Where Israfel/ Hath dwelt, and he where I,/ He might not sing so wildly well/ A mortal melody,/ While a bolder note that this might/ swell/ From my lyre within the sky", lines from Donne's "Of the Progresse of the Soule: The Second Anniversarie", reading "Shee, shee is gone; she is gone; when thou knowest this,/ What fragmentary rubbidge this world is/ Thou knowst, and tha tis not worth a thought;/ He honors it too much that thinks it nought./ Thinke then, my soule, that death is but a Groome,/ Which brings a Taper to the outward roome", lines from Donne's "The Undertaking", reading "But he who lovelinesse within/ Hath found, all outward loathes,/ For he who colour loves, and skinne,/ Loves but their oldest clothes", lines from Vaughan's "The World", reading "I saw Eternity the other night,/ Like a great Ring of pure and endless light,/ All calm, as it was bright;/ And round beneath it, Time in hours, days, years,/ Driven by the spheres/ Like a vast shadow moved; in which the world/ And all her train were hurled", lines reading "Within and out, in and out, round as a ball,/ With hither and thither, as straight as a line/ With lily, germander, and sops-in-wine,/ With sweet-briar/ And bon-fire/ And strawberry wire/ And columbine", lines from Thomson's "In the City of the Dreadful Night", reading "The moving moon and stars from east to west/ Circle before her in the sea of air;/ Shadows and gleams glide round her solemn rest./ Her subjects often gaze up to her there:/ The strong to drink new strength of iron endurance,/ The weak new terrors; all, renewed assurance/ And confirmation of the old despair", lines from Shelley's "A Defence of Poetry", reading "great secret of morals is love; or a going out of our own nature, and an identification of ourselves with the beautiful which exists in thought, action, or person, not our own. A man, to be greatly good, must imagine intensely and comprehensively; he must put himself in the place of another and of many others; the pains and pleasures of his species must become his own. The great instrument of moral good is the imagination; and poetry administers to the effect by acting upon the cause", and lines from von Harbou's Metropolis, reading "I have known those in the ectasy of desire to have forced women down to them from the highest part of the shell's wall, that they, diving, like seagulls, without injuring a limb, while others have fallen to their death. That man there was no God, no Storm, no Fire, and his drunkenness most certainly inspired him with no desire. It seems to me that he has come up from hell and its roaring in the intoxication of damnation. He did not know that the ecstasy for men who are damned is also damnation".  There are two other clippings on the page, one in Russian, and one in Old English reading "Paet is wynsum wong, wealdas grēne,/ rūme under roderum. Ne maeg paēr rēn ne snāw,/ ne forstes fnaest, ne fyres blaest,/ ne haegles hryre, ne hrīmes dryre,/ ne sunnan haetu, ne sincieldu,/ ne wearm weder, ne winterscūr/ wihte gewyrdan:". Morgan has added a small pink ink doodle to the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: The center of the page is taken up by an article titled "The Ancient Peruvian" from Zoo magazine's Animals in Art series. The clipping includes two photographs, one captioned as a "Close-up of the so-called Chincha bulldog modelled in black Chimu potter and found at Trugillo in North Peru" and one captioned as "A bitch and puppies modelled in pottery in the form of a whistle. The finger-holes are in the tops of the puppies' heads, and the contrivance produces high, piping notes". Below this clipping, and the only other image-based clipping on the page is a colour photograph of three colourful beetles. Around these clippings are several text-based clippings, including lines from Traherne's "Amendment", reading "That all things should be mine,/ This makes His bounty most divine./ But that they all more rich should be,/ And far more brightly shine,/ As used by me;/ It ravishes my soul to see the end,/ To which this work so wonderful doth tend", lines from Hopkins' "Heaven-Haven", reading "I have desired to go/ Where springs not fail,/ To fields where flies no sharp and sided hail/ And a few lilies blow./ And I have asked to be/ Where no storms come,/ Where the green swell is in the havens dumb,/ And out of the swing of the sea", lines from Traherne's "The Anticipation", reading "His Essence is all Act: He did that He/ All Act might always be./ His nature burns like fire;/ His goodness infinitely does desire/ To be by all possess;/ His love makes others blest./ It is the glory of His high estate,/ And that which I for evermore admire,/ He is an Act that doth communicate", lines from Traherne's "My Spirit", reading "O wonderous Self! O sphere of light,/ O sphere of joy most fair;/ O act, O power infinite;/ O subtile and unbounded air!/ O living orb of sight!/ Thou which within me art, yet me! Thou eye,/ And temple of His whole infinity!", a Middle English prayer, reading "God send vs the dew of heuene and Reyn fro the cloudes of heuene, and thirlethe our erthe and open our land, and bring forth a blome of sich feng and sich fuysoun That be our bote and our savacioun", lines from Traherne's "The Vision", reading "Flight is but the preparative. The sight/ Is deep and infinite,/ Ah me! 'tis all the glory, love, light, space, / Joy, beauty and variety/ That doth adorn the Godhead's dwelling-place;/ 'Tis all that eye can see", lines from Milton's Paradise Lost, reading "an Iland salt and bare,/ The haunt of Seales and Orcs, and Sea-mews clang", a handwritten clipping (like in Old English), which looks to read "Dā cōm wederes blaest,/ Hādor heofonlēorna, ofer hofu blīcan", lines from "Sir Patrick Spens" that read "O lang, lang, may the ladyes sit,/ Wi' their fans into their hand,/ Before they see Sir Patrick Spens/ Come sailing to the strand!", and two clippings, possibly from the same source, that discuss the small fraction of notes in the songs of birds that the human ear is able to hear, as well as efforts to record and transpose these notes to make them audible to humans. Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: The center of the page is taken up by two clippings. The first is from Zoo Magazine's Animals in Art series and shows two paintings, one captioned as "A Persian painting 300 years old, now in the British Museum. It is a piece of pure rhythmic composition, each galloping horse having its own rhythm and all their rhythms linking together", and the second as "An Indian painting of the Rajput school which shows water-buffaloes fighting. The clever composition stresses the powers of force and weight in conflict". The second clipping is titled "A Guernsey Idol" and includes a black and white photograph of a stone female figure that is currently a gatepost at St Martin's Church. The article speculates that the figure was an idol and was buried at St Martin's Church in Guernsey as a way to prevent people from worshipping it. The article also states that "not that many years ago" (the article was written in 1938), a churchwarden attempted to break the idol up. It was saved, but not before being broken in half. It has now been cemented back together. Around these two clippings are smaller clippings, including a small black and white photograph of a carved stone figure and a small black and white clipping from a painting that appears to show peacock feathers, among other objects. The text-based clippings include lines from Edward Lear's "The Jumblies", reading "Far and few, far and few,/ Are the lands where the Jumblies live;/ Their heads are green, and their hands are blue,/ And they went to sea in a sieve", lines from Lear's "The Courtship of the Yonghy-Bonghy-Bo", reading "On the Coast of Coromandel/ Where the early pumpkins blow,/ In the middle of the woods/ Lived the Yonghy-Bonghy-Bò", lines from William Bell Scott's "The Witch's Ballad", reading "Each one in her wame shall hide/ Her hairy mouse, her wary mouse,/ Fed on madwort and agramie,/ Wear amber beads between her breasts,/ And blind-worm's skin about her knee", lines from "The Elfin Knight", reading "Say, can you plough me an acre of land,/ Sing Ivy Leaf, Sweet William and Thyme,/ Between the sea and the salt sea strand,/ And you shall be a true lover of mine", lines from Percy Bysshe Shelley's "Adonais", reading "Like pageantry of mist on an autumnal stream", Latin lines from Catullus's "Poem 63", reading "dea, magna dea, Cybelle, dea, domina, Dindimei, procul a mea tuos sit furor omnis, hera, domo: alios age incitatos, alios age rabidos", lines from T.S. Eliot's "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock", reading "I have seen them riding seaward on the waves/ Combing the white hair of the waves blown back/ When the wind blows the water white and black./ We have lingered in the chambers of the sea/ By sea-girls wreathed with seaweed red and brown/ Till human voices wake us, and we drown", lines from Lewis Carroll's Though the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There, reading "He said, 'I look for butterflies/ That sleep among the wheat:/ I make them into mutton-pies,/ And sell them in the street", lines from the Bhagavad-Gita, reading "66. Surrendering all the laws, come for refuge to me alone. I will deliver thee from all sins; grieve not", lines from Durrell's Zero and Asylum in the Snow, reading "On Tuesday there will be a jeweled hush, an audit. The walks will be dressed in snow, the bushes incandescent with birds. Everything fallen in a divine abyss of lull, poem, zodiac, frost, butter. Perhaps to-day is the day, I do not know. I find it difficult to tell until I hear the motor, the fourteen horses crushing the jewels, and the doors of God opening", and lines from "Here We Come A-wassailing", reading "God bless the master of this house,/ Likewise the mistress too;/ And all the little children/ That round the table go:". Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: The top of this page shows three black and white images: a photograph showing the shadows of leaves on a tree branch, and two black and white reproductions of grisaille paintings of saints included in the same clipping, one of St Syriacus and one of St Lawrence, both by Matthias Grünewald. In between the two clippings a colour drawing of a Chital, likely from a cigarette card, and a text-based clipping describing a titled woman who was reduced to selling onions on the street are pasted in. Above the images, Morgan has included small lines of text, including a handwritten clipping quoting Beowulf, reading "Gewāt dā ofer waegholm winde gefysed/ Flota fāmiheals fugle gelīcost . . .", a line from Lawrence Durrell that reads "the vortex of language comes up in my throat like a soft ball of blood", the whole of the poem "Man" by Vaughn, lines from Traherne's "Love", reading I am His image, and His friend,/ His son, bride, glory, temple, end", lines from Hopkins's "To R. B.", reading "The roll, the rise, the carol, the creation", lines from Vaughan's "Corruption", reading "Almighty Love! Where art thou now? Man man/ Sits down, and freezeth on,/ He raves, and swears to stir nor fire, nor fan,/ But bids the thread to be spun", a paragraph describing Maid Olwen from The Mabinogion, beginning "The maiden was clothed in a robe of flame-coloured silk, and about her neck was a collar of ruddy gold, on which were precious emeralds and rubies" and ending "Four white trefoils sprung up wherever she trod. And therefore was she called Olwen", lines from Ovid's "Heroides" that read "adest, adest fax obuoluta sanguine atque incendio", lines from George Herbert's "The Temper (I)", reading "Whether I flie with angels, fall with dust,/ Thy hands made both, and I am there:/ Thy power and love, my love and trust/ Make one place ev'rywhere", lines from Hume's "Day Estival", reading "Calm is the deep and purpour sea,/ Yea, smoother nor the sand,/ The waves that woltring wont to be,/ Are stable like the land", lines of a prayer reading "'O God,' he cried, 'if there be a God, save my soul, if I have a soul'", lines from Genesis 39:2, reading "And the Lorde was with Joseph, and he was a luckie felowe", and lines from Marvell's "The Garden", reading "Meanwhile the mind, from pleasure less,/ Withdraws into its happiness;/ The mind, that ocean where each kind/ Does straight its own resemblance find;/ Yet it creates, transcending these,/ Far other worlds, and other seas,/ Annihilating all that's made/ To a green thought in a green shade". Image-based clippings on the page include a photograph of an etched coat of arms, a black and white photograph of a vase full of flowers, a photograph of an elephant's tusk, captioned as "Elephant's tusk shell (Dentalium)", a photograph of a clock face, a photograph of the front and back of a compass, and a reproduction of a small landscape scene showing Greek columns. The page also contains two Britannia articles. The first is titled "The Legend of Dozmary Pool (Bodmin Moors, Cornwall)", describing a pool thought to be bottomless and haunted by "the spirit of Tregeagle, a man of position and wealth" who sold himself to the Devil. The second is "The Mermaid of Zennor (Cornwall)", which describes a beautiful woman who mysteriously appeared in Zennor and lured away a local man. Neither were seen again, until years later, sailors saw a mermaid who they recognized as the woman. She asked the sailors to move their anchor, "as it was barring the entrance to her house". This page also includes a French clipping annotated by Morgan as being from "'Vu' 21.8.38" and titled "Le 'Génie' vu par les Américains", which reads "A trois ans, la charmante Joan Fontaine fut conduit à l'Université de Stanford, où elle subit, sans trop s'en rendre compte, un "examen d'intelligence". Elle répondit aux questions et totalisa 160 points. 150 points suffisent, paraît-il à révéler un génie. -A trois ans, déclare aujourd'hui Joan. Je fus donc déclarée génie. Depuis, mes facultés n'ont pas cessé de s'atténuer avec une régularité magnifique et j'espère qu'à vingt et un ans je serai tout à fait normale". Blue and pink ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles, Morgan's drawing of the Tifinagh scipt
pages.desc: This page is a predominantly text-based, with two larger clippings centered on the page. The first is an article from The Times titled "Fairies in Ireland", a letter written to the editor of The Times describing reports in the Dublin Irish Press of increases in sightings of fairies around West Limerick. The sighted fairies, or leprechauns, are described as being "clean and neat", "about 2ft. in height" and having "hard, hairy faces like men, and no ears". The other clipping is a handwritten clipping showing Morgan's rendering in blue ink of Tifinagh Script, which Morgan has copied from text at the Museé de l'Homme, Paris. Other clippings on the page include two colour photographs of beetles, one red and one green, a black and white reproduction of a painting showing a man wading through water between two cliffs or pillars with a child on his shoulders, and three small black and white clippings that are difficult to make out and appear to be decorative in purpose. Also on the page are various text-based clippings, including lines from an article in The New Yorker, reading "Scented Saddle Horses for Hire", lines that read "And still at every Christmas time/ I see the old man sit/ And suck on at his oranges/ And sit and sit and sit", lines from Shelley's "To Jane: The Invitation reading "When the night is left behind,/ In the deep east, dun and blind,/ And the blue noon is over us,/ And the multitudinous/ Billows murmur at our feet,/ Where the earth and ocean meet,/ And all things seem only one/ In the universal sum", lines from Shelley's "Music when Soft Voices Die (To --)", reading "Music, when soft voices die,/ Vibrates in the memory-/ Odours, when sweet violets sicken,/ Live within the sense they quicken./ Rose leaves, when the rose is dead,/ Are heaped for the beloved bed;/ And so thy thoughts, when thou art gone,/ Love itself shall slumber on", two clippings from Shelley's "Adonais", one reading "He is made one with Nature: there is heard/ His voice in all her music, from the moan/ Of thunder, to the song of night's sweet bird;/ He is a presence to be felt and known/ In darkness and in light, from herb and stone,/ Spreading itself where'er that Power may move/ Which has withdrawn his being to its own;" and the other reading "That Light whose smile kindles the Universe,/ That Beauty in which all things work and move,/ That Benediction which the eclipsing Curse/ Of birth can quench not, that sustaining Love/ Which through the web of being blindly wove/ By man and beast and earth and art and sea,/ Burns bright or dim, as each are mirrors of/ The fire for which all thirst; now beams on me,/ Consuming the last clouds of cold mortality", lines from Hopkins' "Thou art indeed just, Lord, if I contend", reading "Wert thou my enemy, O thou my friend,/ How wouldst thou worse, I wonder, than thou dost/ Defeat, thwart me? Oh, the sots and thralls of lust/ Do in spare hours more thrive than I that spend,/ Sir, life upon thy cause. See, banks and brakes/ Now, leaved how thick! Laced they are again/ With fretty chervil, look, and fresh wind shakes/ Them; birds build-but not I build; no, but strain,/ Time's eunuch, and not breed one work that wakes./ Mine, O thou lord of life, send my roots rain", lines from Barrington's "My Love is Theosophist", reading "My love is a Theosophist/ And reads the Ramāyana;/ Her luncheon is a pot of tea,/ Her breakfast a banana", lines from Durrell's "Island Fugue", reading "The blue, the cool, the curious sea,/ Her blunt mesmeric pendulum/ Swings in the heart of things to dumb/ Our volumes of philosophy", lines from the anonymous poem "Sonnet Found in a Deserted Mad-House", reading "Ah, no Love, not while your hot kisses burn/ Like a potato riding on the blast", a paragraph from Milton's Paradise Lost, beginning "O fairest of Creation, last and best/ Of call Gods Works" and ending "Flesh of Flesh,/ Bone of my Bone thou art, and from thy State/ Mine never shall be parted, bliss or woe" and a paragraph from Le Morte d'Arthur, beginning "And then she was wrapped in cered cloth of Raines, from the top to the toe, in thirtyfold; and after she was put in a web of lead, and then in a coffin of marble" and ending "For when I remember of her beauty, and of her noblesse, that was both with her king and with her, so when I saw his corpse and her corpse so lie together, truly mine heart would not serve to sustain my careful body". Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

This page contains a number of images, including a colour photograph of an orange and black beetle, a colour photograph of a yellow and black beetle, a colour clipping of an drawn design, a black and white photograph of an etched Etruscan bronze mirror, captioned as "Orion crossing the sea. Bronze mirror. Etruscan; about 500 B.C.", a black and white photograph of an ornate carved horn, a black and white photograph of a bust, a black and white photograph of mountain cliffs, a black and white drawing of a rooster standing in front of a mirror, a black and white photograph showing five diatoms, a black and white photograph of an Iranian battle-axe, captioned as "(B) Battle-axe, from Luristan, Iran. c. 1000 B.C.", a black and white photograph of an ornate circular object captioned as "[In Victoria and Albert Museum] An embossed Mirror-back with Greco-Bactrian designs. Han Dynasty (202 B.C. - A.D. 220). Chinese art owes much to Greek influence", onto which Morgan has added a note that reads "Story of the Nations". Also included on this page is clipping reporting on Mr. William Barnes, who is considered to be a healer. He is quoted as stating that he can even heal those who don't believe, making it different to faith healing. Other paranormal activities, including crockery moving and breaking on its own, ghostly images appearing on blank photographic plates, and wood burning when Barnes touches it, are also reported. A second text-based clipping is titled "The Deep's Deepest Mystery" and is excerpted by the Reader's Digest from The Log of Bob Bartlett. This clipping describes the Mary Celeste, a ship that was sailing from New York to Genoa in 1872. On 5 December, a British brigantine intercepted the Mary Celeste, finding the ship entirely empty, with no signs of violence, struggle, or corpses. The article reports that no information on the disappearance has ever surfaced. There are two other small clippings on the page, one from the Mahābhārata, reading "13. Hateless toward all born beings, friendly, and pitiful, void of the thought of a Mine and an I, bearing indifferently pain and pleasure, patient", and one from the Bhagavad Gita, reading "Malancha samupadaya | kanchanim samalamkritam/ Avatirna tato rangam | Draupadi Bharatarshabha".

pages.notes: pink ink doodles
pages.desc: This page contains a large black and white photograph of a mural on the west wall of the Dura-Europos synagogue. The photograph is from a French language source, indicated by the caption, which reads "La Synagogue de Doura - Mur oust, côté gauche de la niche". The other main clipping on the page is a large clipping titled "Deux Tableau de Quentin Metsys acquis par le gouvernment de l'État Portugais", which discusses the acquisition of the "Presentation of Christ in the Temple" and "Lamentation after the Death of Christ" for two and a half million francs. The article includes black and white reproductions of the two paintings.
