The page also includes a colour photograph of a bumble bee, some small black and white indistinct decorative clippings, a black and white photograph with the caption "with a magnification of 125 diameters, the camera caught this view of an eye's retina", which Morgan has annotated as being from December 1934 Popular Science, lines from Keats's "The Fall of Hyperion - A Dream", reading "'None can usurp this height,' return'd that shade,/ 'But those to whom the miseries of the world/ 'Are misery, and will not let them rest",  lines Edward Thomas's "Two Pewits", reading "While the moon's quarter silently/ Rides, and earth rests as silently", and lines from Gascoyne's Miserere, reading "Holds Him god has forsaken, Word made flesh/ Made ransom, to the slow smoulder of her heart/ Till the catharsis of the race shall be complete", and a brief paragraph describing the Grand Coulee Dam as a structure that will replace the Pyramid of Cheops as the largest manmade structure. Small pink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: The page includes two black and white reproductions of paintings by Grünwald, the first of which is the Stuppach Madonna, captioned as "Photo Kirchenstiftungsrat, Stuppach 55. La Vierge de Stuppach (1519) - Stuppach, Église paroissiale" and the second is the portrait of Thomas von Rieneck, captioned as "Photo Braun 58. Portrait de Thomas de Rieneck (detail) (1528) - Cologne, Musée Wallraf-Richartz". Other images on the page include a colour photograph of a moth, a black and white drawing of a moth with folded wings, a black and white photograph of an ornate teacup, a black and white photograph of a pine tree covered in snow, a black and white photograph of snow drifts, a black and white photograph of what looks like a tube or possibly a cocoon, a small black and white photograph of a stone relieve carving, and a colour photograph of a moth with outstretched wings. On the lower part of the page, various text-based clippings include lines from Sir Walter Raleigh's "Now What is Love?", reading "Now what is love, I pray thee tell?/ It is that fountain and that well,/ Where pleasure and repentance dwell./ It is perhaps the sauncing bell/  That tolls us into heaven or hell,/ And this is love, as I hear tell", and lines from Donne's "The Expostulation", reading "Sooner I'll thinke the Sunne will cease to cheare/ The teeming earth, and that forget to beare,/ Sooner that rivers will runne back, or Thames/ With ribs of Ice in June would bind his streames,/ Or Nature, by whose strength the world endures,/ Would change her course, before you alter yours", a version of the "two cows" political satire (this one including New Dealism: "If you have two cows, you shoot one and milk the other; then you pour the milk down the drain"), a clipping reading "To make football practice more attractive, Glendale, Cal., Junior College boys use for a tackling dummy a life-size figure made up like a glamorous movie star, wearing tights, a curly wig, and long gloves. -Springfield (Mass.) Union", and a paragraph describing a scene in which Mrs. Amos Pinchot dreams that she had written the best poem of her age, jotted it down half asleep, and awoke the next day to read "Hogamus Higamus / Men are Polygamous / Higamus Hogamus / Women Monogamous". Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: blue ink doodle
pages.desc: Along the top of the page is a large black and white photograph of a pillar from the Egyptian Temple of Senusret, which depicts a vulture with an ankh in its claws. The image is captioned as "Temple de Sésostris Ier, à Karnak (Egypte) -Détail d'un pilier -Vautour tenant dans ses serres la croix de Vie" and Morgan has annotated the clipping with the source and date. Below this clipping is a black and white photograph of berries and leaves, a small cartoonish colour drawing of a dragon's head, a black and white photograph of the sky, a black and white photograph of a mask, a black and white photograph of a clock face showing 7:49, and a black and white photograph of a carved stone frieze, likely excerpted from a larger work. Text-based clippings include Sanskrit lines from the Mahābhārata, lines from the Bhagavad-gita, reading "If one of earnest spirit set before me with devotion a leaf,/ a flower, fruit, or water, I enjoy this offering of devotion", lines from the Upanishads reading "20. Only when men shall roll up the sky like a hide, will there be an end of misery, unless God has first been known", lines from Keats's "Hyperion" reading "'A voice came sweeter, sweeter than all tune,/ 'And still it cried, 'Apollo! young Apollo!/ ''The morning-bright Apollo! young Apollo!/ 'I fled, it follow'd me, and cried 'Apollo!'", lines reading "Heliotrop, rosemary, crocus and palm/ All aromatics aspire to the Sun", lines reading "Moon hath lettuce, apple and pear,/ Swelleth out gourd and cucumber", a line reading "grosse Dummheit (great boner)", lines from Ogden Nash's "The Rhinoceros Poem", reading "Farewell, farewell, you old rhinoceros,/ I'll stare at something less prepoceros", and a clipping describing U.S. Air Force Lieutenant Roy Keith's experience of passing out due to an oxygen failure 28,000 feet in the air, causing his plane to dive and hit speeds of 670 m.p.h. As a result, the pilot and his plane reached the fastest speeds any man had travelled before. A large paragraph from Swedenborg's Heaven and its Wonders and Hell discusses the importance of turning thoughts and will into action. A handwritten clipping quoting lines from Dylan Thomas's "Unluckily for a death" reads "All LOVE but for the full assemblage in flower/ Of the living flesh is monstrous or immortal,/ And the grave its daughters". One blue ink doodle decorates the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: The top of the page shows a black and white reproduction of Da Vinci's Heads of Sts Thomas and James the Greater, as well as a black and white photograph of a sculpture captioned as "A Sumptuous Sumerian Chariot Fitting: A silver and electrum rein-ring from Queen Shub-Ad's chariot pole; dating from 3200 B.C. - found by Sir Leonard Woolley in the Royal Graves at Ur and now in the British Museum. (Height: 5 1/4 In.)". Morgan has annotated the clipping as being from "ILN". Pasted onto the corners of the chariot fitting clipping are a colourful drawing of a creature, likely from the same source as the dragon head on the previous page, and a black and white image that is difficult to make out, but may be a cocoon. Below these clippings is a black and white reproduction of Giovanni's etching "View of a Town with The Bishop's Tomb, From The Vedute". Next to this reproduction, Morgan has written lines from Horace, reading "iam pastor umbras cum grege languido rivomque fessus quaerit . . .", onto the scrapbook page. Morgan has included a large clipping titled "The Ladybird in Folklore" from the Observer, which discusses Sir Jacob Grimm's theory that the legends surrounding ladybirds and goldbeetles are "relics of prehistoric beetle-worship", linking these beetles to the Virgin Mary and Freya, Northern goddess of Spring and Love. The bottom of the ladybird clipping has been folded up to make it fit the page, and on the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of an Egyptian statue. Morgan has also included a clipping of the entire poem "Nod" by de la Mar, which Morgan has written out by hand, a black and white reproduction of a drawing showing two men, one carrying something heavy and one walking with a stick, likely a detail from a larger work, a black and white photograph of two objects that are difficult to make out, and a black and white drawing of a duck in flight, likely excerpted from a larger image. Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: A large black and white reproduction of Claude's painting "Le Chateau Enchanté" (The Enchanted Castle) dominates this page. Morgan has annotated the clipping as "'La Belle France' April 1937 Claude Gellee (1600-82)". Arranged around the edges of the painting are small black and white photographs, largely decorative, showing the borders of friezes and carvings. One small clipping appears to be a photograph of a coin, or similar metallic object, bearing an image of a cow. The text-based clippings include two separate clippings with lines from Shelley's "Adonais: An Elegy on the Death of John Keats", the first reading "He has outsoared the shadow of our night;/ Envy and calumny and hate and pain,/ And that unrest which men miscall delight,/ Can touch him not and torture not again;" and the second reading "He is a portion of the loveliness/ which once he made more lovely: he doth bear/ His part, while the one Spirit's plastic stress/ Sweets through the dull dense world", lines from Traherne's "Dumbness" reading "No ear/ But eyes themselves were all the hearers there,/ And every stone, and every star a tongue,/ And every gale of wind a curious song", Latin lines from Lucretius's De Rerum Natura, reading "ergo uiuida uis animi peruicit, et extra/ processit longe flammantia moenia mundi/ atque omne immensum peragrauit mente animoque", lines from Lucretius's The World and the Man, reading "in caeloque deum sedis et templa locarunt,/ per caelum uolui quia sol et luna uidetur,/ luna dies et nox et noctis signa seuera/ noctiuagaeque faces caeli flammaeque uolantes,/ nubile sol imbres nix uenti fulmina grando/ et rapidi fremitus et murmura magna minarum", a passage that appears to be in a Cyrillic alphabet, a passage from the Bhagavad-gita reading "8. I am the taste in the water, O son of Kuntī; I am the light in moon and sun, the Om in all the Vedas, sound in the ether, manhood in men. 9. The pure scent in earth am I, and the light in fire; the life in all born beings am I, and the mortification of them that mortify the flesh", French lines from Racine's Phèdre, reading "Cet heureux temps n'est plus. Tout a change de face,/ Depuis que sur ces bords les Dieux ont envoyé/ La fille de Minos et de Pasiphaé", and lines from Beowulf reading "Gistas sétan/ Mōdes sēoce ond on mere staredon;/ Wiston ond ne wēndon dost hīe heora wine drihten/ Selfnie gesāwon" that Morgan has copied out by hand. Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

The top half of this page is taken up by a large black and white reproduction of Botticelli's Madonna with Child and Singing Angels (Raczyński Tondo). In the four corners of this larger clipping are four black and white images: top left is a reproduction of a painting of six birds, bottom left is a reproduction of a painting of a sailing ship at sea, bottom right is a reproduction of a painting of two sailing ships out in stormy seas, and top right is a reproduction of a surrealist painting depicting a man in front of a fireplace with racing dogs and foxes dressed as men swirling around him. The bottom of the page is taken up by a large black and white photograph of a winged insect. Morgan has written in the top left corner of the clipping that the insect is "In amber".

The center of this page is taken up by a large clipping from Beaus-Arts titled "Le génie et la folie de Van Gogh", which discusses some connections between mental illness and great artists. The top of the clipping has been folded over so that it will fit the page, and on the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a ship sailing in water next to a long stretch of ice. Above the Van Gogh clipping, Morgan has written on to the scrapbook page the lines "I shall breathe the sweet breath which comes forth from thy mouth. I shall behold they beauty every day. It is my desire that I may hear thy sweet voice, even the north wine, that I may receive new life thru love of thee. Give me thy hands, holding thy spirit, that I may receive it and live by it. Call thou upon my name thruout eternity, and it shall never fail", which is an Egyptian prayer found, for example, on the coffin in Tutankhamen's tomb. Below the clipping, Morgan has included a small black and white photograph of mountains at a distance, which is likely excerpted from a larger image, as well as a handwritten clipping with verses from Edward Thomas's "Tall Nettles", reading "Tall nettles cover up, as they have done/ These many springs, the rusty harrow, the plough/ Long worn out, and the roller made of stone:/ Only the elm butt tops the nettles now./ This corner of the farmyard I like most:/ As well as any bloom upon a flower/ I like the dust on the nettles, never lost/ Except to prove the sweetness of a shower",  a clipping from Donne's "The Lamentations of Jeremy, for the most part according to Tremellius", reading "13 Hee made the children of his quiver passe/ Into my reines, 14 I with my people was/ All the day long, a song and mockery./ 15 Hee hath fill'd mee with bitternesse, and he/ Hath made me drunke with wormewood. 16 He hath burst/ My teeth with stones, and covered mee with dust;" and lines from Chaucer's The Wife of Bath Prolouge from Canterbury Tales, reading "But, lord Crist! Whan that it remembreth me/ Up-on my yowthe, and on my jolitee,/ It tikleth me aboute myn herte rote./ Unto this day it dooth myn herte bote/ That I have had my world as in my tyme".

pages.notes: blue and pink ink doodles
pages.desc: The center of this page features a large colour reproduction of Guardi's L'Isola de San Giorgo painting from Italia. The clipping has been folded on the right side to make it fit into the scrapbook. On the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph captioned as the "Old Age Pensions Institute in Prague, by Havlicke and Honzik, 1934", as well as an article from the Bulletin bearing a subtitle of "Fingers Burned", which describes a demonstration in Venice by Professor R.W. Wood. The demonstration showed a slab of quartz being subjected to "an oscillating current of 280,000 periods a second and 50,000 volts tension" in a bowl of oil. A glass of water containing a live fish was then placed in the oil, causing the fish to die. The demonstration also showed hands being burned by touching glass that had been placed in the oil, despite the glass not being heated. The article closes by saying it is unclear in the fish experiment whether "it is that ultra-sonic waves heat the body to such an extent as to cause death, or whether death is determined by the liberation of the gases forming part of the blood". Along the top of the page, an Old English paragraph has been clipped, as has a newspaper photograph from the Bulletin showing a sandstone slab with hieroglyphics and captioned as "This sandstone slab, measuring three feet in length, with raised hieroglyphics, has been discovered on the farm of Garth, Harray, Orkney". Along the bottom of the page, Morgan has pasted two clippings from Sonnet XXXVII of Griffin's Fidessa sonnet sequence, the first reading "Fair is my love that feeds among the lilies,/ The lilies growing in that pleasant garden,/ Where cupid's mount, that well-beloved hill is,/ And where the little god himself is warden" and the second reading "See where my love sits in the bed of spices,/ Beset all round with camphor, myrrh and roses,/ And interlaced with curious devices,/ Which her from all the world apart incloses". Morgan has also included a black and white photograph, which he has labelled as being from Women's Journal and depicting "Eggs of Mantis", and three verses from Joyce's "Strings in the Earth and Air, reading "Strings in the earth and air/ Make music sweet;/ Strings by the river where/ The williows meet./ There's music along the river/ For Love wanders there,/ Pale flowers on his mantle,/ Dark leaves on his hair./ All softly playing,/ With head to the music bent,/ And fingers straying/ Upon an instrument."

The center of this page features a large colour reproduction of Giotto's painting "The Burial of St. Francis" from Italia. The clipping has been folded on the left side to make it fit the scrapbook, and on the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted a newspaper photograph of a baby from the Bulletin, captioned as "Pauline Sinclair, now nine weeks old" who "was born with a full head of hair, the hair being three inches long", as well as a black and white photograph of a building, captioned as "An elementary school at Villejuif, a suburb of Paris, by André Lurçat, 1932". Along the top of the page, Morgan has included an Old English paragraph, a clipping in a Cyrillic alphabet, lines from The Pardoner's Tale in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, reading "Thus walke I, lyk a resteless caityf, (400)/ And on the ground, which is my modres/ gate,/ I knokke with my staf, bothe erly and late,/ And seye, 'level moder, leet me in! 731/ Lo, how I vanish, flesh and blood, and/ skin!/ Allas! whan shul my bones been at reste?", and the lines "seuen fold yron gates of grislie Hell / And horrid house of sad Proserpina" from Spenser's "The Ruines of Time". Along the bottom of the page, Morgan has clipped verses from Vaughn's "Childhood", reading "I cannot reach it; and my striving eye/ Dazzles at it, as at eternity./ Were now that chronicle alive,/ Those white designs which children drive,/ And the thoughts of each harmless hour,/ With their content too in my pow'r,/ Quickly would I make my path ev'n,/ And by mere playing to to heaven./ Why should men love/ A wolf, more than a lamb or dove?/ Or choose hell-fire and brimstone streams/ Before bright stars and God's own beams?", a paragraph from The Tale of Melibee in The Canterbury Tales, reading "Therefore I receive yow to my grace,/ and foryeve yow outrely alle the offences, injuries, and wronges, that ye have doon agayn me and myne;/ to this effect and to this ende, that god of his endelees mercy / wole at the tyme of our dyinge foryeven us our giltes that we han trespassed to him in this wrecched world. / For doutelees, if we be sory and repentant of the sinnes and giltes whiche we han trespassed in the sighte of our lord god, / he is so free and so merciable,/ that he wole foryeven us our giltes, / and bringen us to his blisse that never hath ende", and lines from Tennyson's "Ulysses", reading "It may be that the gulfs will wash us down:/ It may be that we shall touch the Happy Isles,/ And see the great Achilles, whom we knew./ Though much is taken, much abides; and though/ We are not now that strength which in old days/ Moved earth and heaven; that which we are, we are;/ One equal temper of heroic hearts,/ Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will/ To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield".

This page features a large clipping of four black and white captioned photographs of various clay pots, one a "footed cup in grey clay with black decoration", one a "multiple vessel (of grey clay)", one "a large grey cup with black decoration, including a frieze of panthers at the top just under the rim", which is also said to be "an example of syalck ware in the third millennium B.C. after the adoption of the potter's wheel", and one without a caption in this clipping that resembles a teapot and looks somewhat like a bird. Around the larger clipping Morgan has pasted smaller images, including decorative black and white photographs of ornate carvings, a photograph of a carved Asian figure (possibly a full statue, although the clipping shows only the head and shoulders), a black and white photograph of a relief carving of a person, and a reproduction of a drawing of a mountain, which is captioned "Mount Hor". This page also includes two short articles. The first is from the Evening News and reports Professor Jansky's claims that he has "received short-wave radio signals which originate from some station beyond the earth", the basis for which claim he cites as the fact that the signals "take three to fifteen seconds to reach his receiver," fixing "the place of their origin at a spot many millions of miles from the earth". Jansky says that he will "construct the most powerful shortwave receiver in the world, so that he can study these signals more closely," and reminds cynics that extraterrestrial communication is possible, given that "our more powerful military short-wave transmitters send signals that could be received in the moon if anyone happened to be there". The second article is from the Bulletin and is titled "Chilled Himself Into Insanity: Land of Errors". It describes Sir Joseph Barcroft's efforts to explore the "borderland of insanity by chilling his body to the early stages of freezing" in order to "pass beyond the 'censorship of the mind'. He says he chilled himself to the degree that "nerve censorship" let go, and he found that "he had no natural apprehension lest some person alien to the experiment should enter the room and find him unclad". Barcroft also describes experiments wherein he inhaled carbon dioxide to enter "a sort of 'land of errors'" where "mistakes seemed absolutely correct".

Two clippings on this page are from the same source as the display of clay pottery on page 251 and likewise shows captioned black and white photographs of pottery. The first clipping is captioned as a "terra-cotta pitcher with a flattened spout, and lie-de-vin decoration: A striking example from the many hundreds of painted pottery vessels found in Necropolis B at Syalck" and a second pot is captioned as "somewhat resembling, in shape, a modern teapot, with a particularly long spout: A vessel made of yellow clay found in a grave in Necropolis B, and decorated in the same style as that seen in the adjoining illustration". Onto this clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of an ornate decorative carving showing two birds, possibly storks, photographed with a string of pearls lying at the base. The second artifact clipping shows three objects, one a pot "decorated with fabulous animals, horned and winged, a painted 'collar' round the spout, and geometrical designs: A vase from Necropolis B in yellowish terra-cotta", one "a small bronze harness bell", and one "a pendant ornament in repoussé silver: An example of delicate metal-work, with a cross-shaped design, from Necropolis B". This page also includes a black and white newspaper photograph of a lawn, captioned as showing "The crescent-shaped Sun images seen under trees at the time of a total eclipse", a black and white photograph of a woman from Prediction, captioned as "Below, a remarkable photograph of Eleanora Zugun, showing the stigmatic phenomena taking place on her face. (Both photographs reproduced by courtesy of the University of London Council for Psychical Research)". Other clippings include a black and white reproduction of a drawing of twisting and entwined tubes, captioned as "Vermetus" and annotated by Morgan as "Gastropod", a Cyrillic clipping, two clippings from Coleridge's "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner", one reading "He prayeth well, who loveth well/ Both man and bird and beast./ He prayeth best, who loveth best/ All things both great and small;/ For the dear God who loveth us,/ He made and loveth all" and the second reading "The harbor-bay was clear as glass,/ So smoothly it was strewn!/ And on the bay the moonlight lay,/ And the shadow of the moon", a clipping from Milton's Paradise Lost, reading "From Morn/ To Noon he fell, from Noon to dewy Eve,/ A Summers day; and with the setting Sun/ Dropt from the Zenith like a falling Star,/ On Lemnos th' Aegoean Ile" and small decorative black and white images, including a photograph of a clock face and a reproduction of a drawing showing a sailing ship at sea.

pages.notes: blue and pink ink doodles
pages.desc: The top clipping on this page is a short newspaper article from Bulletin titled "Largest Human Brain on Record" and describes a skull that is believed to have "belonged to an Aleut who lived hundreds of years ago." The article argues that he "had a brain capacity of 2005 cubic centimetres", as well as stating that the "average man has a brain capacity of about 1450 cubic centimetres, and the average woman 1300", leading Dr. Hrdlicka to believe "that the skull's owner was probably one of the cleverest men of his day and age". Beside this clipping, another Bulletin newspaper clipping shows a photograph of a large carved ear with hieroglyphics carved around it captioned as "The huge ear carved out in stone and engraved with Egyptian hieroglyphics which has been discovered during excavations at Giza". Other images on the page include a black and white photograph of a large arched church doorway, a long black and white photograph that appears to show a detail of a stone carving, a colour photograph of a red, yellow, blue and green bird with the caption "Wilson's Bird of Paradise", a colour photograph of a red, green, and yellow beetle, a small black and white photograph of a loch and hills, a colour photograph of a red and white starfish, two small black and white decorative photographs that show details of stone carvings, one depicting figures on horseback, and a black and white photograph of a church with many spiked spires. Text-based clippings on the page include a French language excerpt from Racine's Phèdre, reading "Ce n'est plus une ardeur dans mes veines cachée:/ C'est Vénus tout entire à sa proie attaché./ J'ai conçu pour mon crime une juste terreur;/ J'ai pris la vie en haine, et ma flame en horreur./ Je voulais en mourant prendre soin de ma gloire,/ Et dérober au jour une flamme si noire:/ Je n'ai pu soutenir tes larmes, tes combats,/ Je t'ai tout avoué ; je ne m'en repens pas,/ Pourvu que da ma mort respectant les approches,/ Tu ne m'affliges plus par d'injustes reproches,/ Et que tes vains secours cessent de rappeler/ Un reste de chaleur tout prêt à s'exhaler", a Latin language excerpt from Lucretius extending over two clippings, beginning with "nam simula c ratio tua coepit uociferari " and ending with "his ibi me rebus quaedam diuina uoluptas/ percipit atque horror, quod sic natura tua ui/ tam manifesta patens ex omni parte retecta est",  verses from Coleridge's The Rime of the Ancient Mariner, reading "Oh! dream of joy ! is this indeed/ The lighthouse top I see?/ Is this the hill? is this the kirk?/ Is this mine own countree?", lines from Patmore's "A Farewell", reading "The bitter journey to the bourne so sweet/ Seasoning the termless feast of our content/ With tears of recognition never dry", lines from Peele's The Old Wives Tale, beginning with "Huan. Philida, phileridos, pamphilida, florida, flortos:" and ending with "Zan. [aside]. Whoop! now I have my dream. Did you never hear so great a wonder as this, 'Three blue beans in a blue bladder, rattle, bladder, rattle?'", lines from Milton's Areopagitica, reading "To sequester out of this world into Atlantick and Eutopian polities, which never can be drawn into use, will not mend our condition ; but to ordain wisely as in this world of evill, in the midd'st whereof God hath places us unavoidably", a small handwritten clipping reading "Gudbyrne scan/ Heard hondlocen, hringīren scīr/ Song in searwun, dā hīe sele furdum/ In hyra gryregeatwum gangan cwōmon", and lines from The Maitrâyana Upanishad, reading "Thoughts alone cause the round of a new birth and a new death; let a man therefore strive to purify his thoughts. What a man thinks, that he is; this is the old secret". The page also contains two clippings from an article with the subtitles of "Fruit with a Poisonous Breath" and "If Apples Breathed More Slowly". The clippings describe the work of two South African scientists who grew sprouts in "a box through which blew air that had passed over rows of ripe peaches". The sprouts shriveled within a week. Plums were found to have the same effect. The scientists discovered that "ethylene is the culprit" and are now exploring if ethylene could be "used for stopping fruit from ripening too soon," meaning "fresher and better fruit from beyond the seas". The second part of the article discusses work by scientists in England who are working on slowing the rotting of apples by slowing their "breathing". They do so by keeping the apples in "an atmosphere containing small portions of various gases." Pink and blue ink doodles decorate the page.

pages.notes: blue and pink ink doodles
pages.desc: A large clipping discussing the tradition of wood-carving "among the Igbomina and Ekiti sub-tribes of the Yoruba people" is at the center of this page. The article states that wood-carving is in "danger of dying out completely" due to an opening up of the country and devaluing of African art at home. It also discusses a carver named Bamgboye, who is said to be "one of the best of the surviving Yoruba carvers". Next to this clipping is a black and white photograph of a carving, captioned as "A dignified iroko carving representing the head of a Yoruba woman", to which Morgan has added a note reading "by Bamgboye". Around the carving clipping, Morgan has drawn small ink doodles that resemble seaweed and bubbles. Other clippings include two colour images of cartoonish characters, a black and white photograph of a porcelain man holding a cup in one hand and a pitcher in another, a black and white photograph of a frieze showing many figures, and four lines from Racine's Phèdre, reading "Il a vu le Cocyte et les rivages sombres,/ Et s'est montré vivant aux infernales ombres;/ Mais qu'il n'a pu sortir de ce triste sèjour,/ Et repasser les bords qu'on passe sans retour". In the center of the page is a colour drawing of a fish, likely from a cigarette card, captioned as a "Greater Weever-Fish", as well as a large clipping that shows three black and white photographs of a wall-plaque by Bamgboye. The first image shows the entire wall plaque, and is captioned as being "carved on a mahogany plank about four feet long. The scenes from right to left represent the birth, life and death of a hunter. Two of the panels are illustrated on a larger scale below". The second photograph shows the center panel, which is captioned as "Enjoying life: the village chief wearing necklaces and holding fly whisk with musicians and friends", and the third photograph shows the left panel, described as "Death: the wives are mourning and friends are firing dane guns. The body, wrapped in a cloth, is lying on a mat. Above it are some of the dead man's possessions: a hoe, matchet, axe, pocket knife, pipe, carved stool and waist band". Onto this clipping, between the first and second and the second and third images, Morgan has pasted in extra clippings, both of which are black and white photographs that are difficult to make out, although the second photograph may be of a carving of some sort. Other clippings include a black and white reproduction of Gromaire's painting "Le faucheur flamand", depicting a Flemish man hammering out a sickle, and a small clipping reading, "Because her husband came home late once too often Mrs Jane Wolf, of Cape Town, picked up a bottle of methylated spirits, poured it over him, and set him alight. Then when she saw the flames she threw water over him and put the fire out. Mrs Wolf, who is 28 and has three children, pleaded guilty to a charge of assault. Mr Wolf, who was in court carrying a baby, asked the magistrate to let her off with a caution".

This page is taken up largely by a clipping from Chambers's Journal titled Marvellous Memories, detailing great feats of memory from the past and arguing that "In these days of reference books and artificial memory aids, there is a tendency for the art and practice of memory to be neglected", and thus for the faculty of memory to become "atrophied in this restless age". Around the edges of this clipping, Morgan has included several small black and white photographs of various statues, figures, and carvings, a clock face, a knight's chain mail suit, and a coin that appears to feature a bull. Below the clipping is a colour reproduction of Giotto's St Francis and the Birds painting, a black and white image that might be a photograph of the sky, a black and white photograph of a fish's tail, and a black and white photograph of Lehmbruck's "Kneeling Woman" statue. To this last clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a carved ram's head that looks like it may be part of a column's capital. The ram is looking in the same direction of the kneeling woman's back. Below the kneeling woman clipping, Morgan has pasted a single line of text reading "though she ate nothing, she liked it well cooked".

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: The top of this page is taken up by a large colour photograph from the National Geographic of an eclipse, captioned as "the first natural colour photograph of an eclipse ever reproduced, the corona flares into view as the moon blots out the sun". Around the left and right edges of the image, Morgan has pasted in small decorative black and white photographs, including a sun medallion, two separate clippings of clocks, a photograph of a primate, a photograph of a street scene, a photograph of a young man, several small photographs of various carved figures and sculptures, a black and white photograph of a bee that may be dead, and a black and white photograph of a bottle captioned "Nailsea Harvesting Bottle, black and white, circa 1740". At the bottom of the page, Morgan has included a black and white reproduction of Signac's La Baie, and a black and white drawing of a star-shaped object that looks aquatic and is captioned as "Doris.". Above the aquatic image Morgan has written "hoved in a little leaved wood" and framing the caption Morgan has written "Not" and Dusty", creating a line that appears to read "Not Doris. Dusty". Blue and pink ink doodles decorate the page.

The center of this page shows two large black and white photographs from the Life magazine. The top photograph is captioned as "Facsimile of the Papyrus Inscribed with the Hieroglyphic Text of The Book of the Dead. Part of the oldest book in the world. A copy of the book was always placed in the tomb as a safe conduct for the soul on its journey to the world to come." The second photograph is captioned as "Papyrus Inscribed in the Hieratic Character with an Egyptian Romance and Bearing the Names of Antef, Eleventh Dynasty, About B.C. 2600, and Thothmes III, Eighteenth Dynasty, About B.C. 1600." On the left and right of these two photographs, Morgan has pasted a range of black and white photographs, including small black and white photographs of carved stone relief sculptures, a carved mask, a medallion that appears to depict two figures, a clock face, and details from various stone carvings and sculptures, such as sculpted folds of fabric and what appears to be a human figure's leg. Also included is a handwritten clipping with lines of verse from the anonymous Scottish poem "Welcome Eild", reading "As shadow in the sonnies beam/ Or primrose in the winter shower / So all my day is bot ane dream/ And half the sleeping of any hour", and an illustrated article from the Evening News that describes the ways in which Egyptian cultures placed value on certain "juices or 'life-givers'" such as hair, saliva, and tears. The article states that many "old graves when opened are found to contain tiny glass or earthenware vessels known as tear-bottles", which would have been filled with mourners' tears and "laid beside the corpse as 'soul-substance'". The article includes a drawing of two tear-bottles, underneath which is quoted Psalms 56-8: "Put thou my tears into thy bottle: are they not in thy book?" Next to this clipping, Morgan has pasted a clipping of a short description of two men, McDonald and McKinnan, who killed the last Auk to be seen in Britain. The men found the bird, caught it and kept it for three days, before brutally killing it when a storm rose up, thinking the creature to be a witch. Above this clipping, Morgan has written "The Last Great Auk, about 1843:" in ink on the scrapbook page.

pages.notes: pink ink doodles
pages.desc: Much of this page is taken up by black and white photographs of three bronze heads. The first photograph shows all three heads together and is captioned as "Three of the bronze heads excavated this year at Ife. The head on the left (A) weighs 11 lbs. 11 ozs., the center head (B) 20 lbs. 8 ozs., and the one on the right (C) 10 lbs. 5 ozs. The center head measures about 15 ins. from base to crown. The heads are hollow and each has a circular hole about 3 ins. in diameter at the back of the skull". On this clipping, Morgan has written "see 1499", referring to another scrapbook page. Below this clipping is a larger photograph of the head labelled C. The head is shown in profile and the photograph is captioned as "Side view of head (C). The small holes in the face penetrate to the interior. The bronze is about 1/4 in. thick". Onto this clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of cylindrical stones that looks like it might be from the Giant's Causeway in Northern Ireland, as well as a black and white photograph of a man in uniform holding up a large sheet and a black and white image of something that is difficult to make out, but might be a stone carving. Morgan has also added pink ink lines and doodles around the two extra clippings collaged onto the page. Next to the photograph of head (C), Morgan has included a second photograph, this one straight on and close up, of head (B). Around these 3 larger clippings Morgan has included lines from Dunbar's "Lament for the Makers", reading "Our pleasance here is all vain glory,/ This false world is but transitory,/ The flesh is bruckle, the Fiend is slee;/ Timor mortis conturbat me", a coloured cartoonish drawing of what might be a side view of a mask and four coloured dots, a black and white photograph of a carved stone frieze, a black and white full-body profile photograph of a man dressed in Roman costume, a black and white ceramic or porcelain male figure holding a mug, a colour drawing, likely from a cigarette card, showing three prawns, one red, one green and one blue, with the caption "The Aesop Prawn", and an illustration from "Ommie Wise", an American murder ballad, showing the murder of Ommie (or Naomi Wise) at the hands of her lover, John Lewis. Also included are two short articles. The first states that "Cosmic rays destroy on Earth about one atom per cubic centimeter per second", thus attesting to life's "incredible persistence" and "ability to adapt itself to [the] unbelievable rigors" of Earth. The article emphasizes the importance of procreation to the continuance of life, and states that "Our atmosphere is a futile shield against the terrific power of cosmic particles. Only the invisible, intangible defenses of the Sun's vast magnetic field, and Earth's lesser one protect us, make it possible for human beings to have human children, and not give birth to monstrous, unnamable things". The second article is from Picture Post and discusses a "telescope with a lens 100 inches wide" which has been used to photograph Jupiter. These photographs have enabled the discovery of two new moons, bringing the known total to 11. The article then states that when Galileo first posited that Jupiter had four moons, "Certain important Cardinals had no difficulty in proving that Galileo must be wrong. A dignitary named Sizzi roundly said, 'The moons are invisible to the naked eye, and therefore can have no influence on the earth, and therefore would be useless, and therefore do not exist!'". The article concludes by stating that it also appears that Jupiter's sky is "utterly hidden by thick clouds".

This page features two large black and white reproductions of paintings. The first is Schongauer's L'Adoration des Mages, captioned as "Photo Dettiling, Strasbourg 15. L'Adoratoin des Mages Atelier de Schongauer (1475) - Musée de Strasbourg" and the second is Grünewald's The Mocking of Christ. Surrounding these images are other black and white images, including a photograph of a fish, a photograph showing a rat and a cat sitting on a contented-looking dog, a photograph of waves crashing to shore, and two black and white drawings from Jones's General Outline of the Organization of The Animal Kingdom and Manual of Comparative Anatomy. The first of these two drawings is captioned as "Gorgonocephalus", a type of marine sea-basket, and the second is captioned as "Cidaris", or a type of pencil sea urchin. Morgan has also included lines from Milton's The Doctrine and Discipline of Divorce, reading "For though it were granted us by divine indulgence to be exempt from all that can be harmfull to us from without, yet the perversnesse of our folly is so bent, that we should never lin hammering out of our owne hearts, as it were out of a flint, the seeds and sparkles of new misery to our selves, till all were in a blaze againe", and a small article from the Daily Record titled "Speechless" that describes a tribe in the Amazon called the Quurunga who are said not to speak with any verbal language. However, the article does state that the Quurunga make sounds to "denote a state of feeling".

This page features a large black and white photograph of many tombstones in a graveyard and a black and white photograph of the Rosetta Stone from Outline of Literature and Art, which includes a large caption describing the stone's history. Other clippings include a black and white photograph of a lily and lily pads, a small black and white photograph of a stone relief carving, lines from Hopkins's "The Woodlark", reading "The blood-gush blade-gash/ Flame-rash rudred/ Bud shelling or broad-shed/ Tatter-tassel-tangled and dingle-a-dangled/ Dandy-hung dainty head", lines from Milton's Paradise Lost, reading "Not that faire field/ Of enna, where Proserpin gathering flours/ Her self a fairer Floure by gloomie Dis/ Was gatherd, which cost Ceres all that pain/ To seek her through the world", lines from Shelley's "Alastor", reading "when some surprising Spirit,/ Whose light adorned the world around it, leaves/ Those who remain behind, not sobs or groans,/ The passionate tumult of a clinging hope;/ But pale despair and cold tranquillity,/ Nature's vast frame, the web of human things,/ Birth and the grave, that are not as they were", a handwritten clipping reading "The great men sayis that their distress/ Comis for the people's wickedness;/ The people sayis for the transgressioun/ Of great men, and their oppressioun:/ Bot mane will their awin sin confess",, a colour photograph of a bright red starfish, three clock faces, lines from the Latin poem "In Nuptias Iuniae et Mallii" by Catullus, reading "Collis o Heliconiei/ cultor, Vraniae genus,/ qui rapis teneram ad uirum/ Virginem, O Hymenaee Hymen,/ Hymen O Hymenaee;/ Cinge tempora floribus/ suaue olentis amaraci,/ flammeum cape laetus, huc/ Huc ueni, niueo gerens/ luteum pede soccum./ Excitusque hilari die,/ nuptialia concinens/ uoce carmina tinnula,/ Pelle humum pedibus, manu/ pineam quate taedam", and a Cyrillic clipping.

pages.notes: pink ink doodle
pages.desc: This page is taken up mostly by a large black and white clipping that shows the photographs of six women in a grid pattern, each said to be showing hairstyles typical to the countries or regions where the women are from (a similar clipping is pasted in the facing page, 262). The captions on this clipping name New Guinea, South Africa, Cameroons, Central Africa, Sudan and the Tendille tribes of North Kenya. The women, however, are not named. On the top of the clipping, Morgan has pasted the phrase "Ronsard me célébrait du temps que j'étais belle" from Ronsard's poem "Quand vous serez bien vieille". The inside edge of this clipping has been folded over to make it fit into the scrapbook and on the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted in two clippings. The first is a black and white photograph of what looks to be a cracked stone and the second is a black and white photograph of a mask, captioned as "1. Wooden mask wearing lip-plug. Makonde, Port. East Africa". Above the large clipping, Morgan has included a sixth century poem attributed to Gwyddno Garanhir, in which the fallen king curses Seithenin, who brought about his ruin, and a paragraph from Tennyson's Morte d'Arthur, reading "Then Sir Bedivere cried: Ah my lord Arthur, what shall become of me, now ye go from me and leave me here along among mine enemies? Comfort thyself, said the king, and do as well as thou mayest, for in me is no trust for to trust in; for I will into the vale of Avilion to heal me of my grievous wound: and if thou hear never more of me, pray for my soul. But ever the queens and ladies wept and shrieked, that it was pity to hear. And as soon as Sir Bedivere had lost the sight of the barge, he wept and wailed, and so took the forest; and so he went all that night, and in the morning he was ware betwixt two holts hoar, of a chapel and an hermitage". Below the large clipping, Morgan has included a small black and white reproduction of a Turner painting captioned as "Lake Surrounded by Mountains", a paragraph from Jefferies's autobiography The Story of My Heart that reads "Realising that spirit, recognizing my own inner consciousness, the psyche, so clearly, I cannot understand time. It is eternity now. I am in the midst of it. It is about me in the sunshine; I am in it, as the butterfly floats in the light-laden air. Nothing has to come; it is now. Now is eternity; now is the immortal life. Here this moment, by this tumulus, on earth, now; I exist in it" and a paragraph from Milton's Paradise Lost, which reads "Did I request thee, Maker, from my Clay / To mould me Man, did I sollicite thee / From darkness to promote me, or here place / In this delicious Garden? as my Will/ Concurd not to my being, it were but right/ And equal to reduce me to my dust,/ Desirous to resigne, and render back/ All I ceceav'd, unable to performe/ Thy terms too hard, by which I was to hold/ The good I sought not. To the loss of that,/ Sufficient penaltie, why has thou added/ The sense of endless woes? Inexplicable/ Thy Justice seems; yet to say truth, too late, I thus contest". A pink ink spiral doodle decorates the top of the page.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles, including a drawing of a Dragonet by Morgan
pages.desc: This page is taken up mostly by a large black and white clipping that shows the photographs of six women in a grid pattern, each said to be showing hairstyles typical to the countries or regions where the women are from (a similar clipping is pasted in the facing page, 261). The captions name N.E. Congo, Cameroons, Equator, North Kenya, Congo, and the Motuan tribe of Papua. The women, however, are not named. The outside edge of this clipping has been folded to make it fit into the scrapbook. On the back of the fold, Morgan has pasted four black and white images: a photograph of a tree in what looks to be spring, an aerial photograph that seems to depict a rift in the earth, a photograph of several small fish swimming amongst greenery, and a microscope photograph of trypanosomes in a blood smear, captioned as "Trypanosomes de la maladie du sommeil, dans un frottis de sang. Les masses arrondies sont des globules rouges un peu déformés par suite de l'étalement en frottis. Gross. 1 200.". Above the large clipping, Morgan has included the final stanza of Villon's "Les Regrets de la Belle Heaulmiere" reading "Ainsi le bon temps regretons/ Entre nous, povres vielles sottes./ Assises bas, a crouppetons,/ Tout en ung tas comme pelottes,/ A petit feu de chenevottes/ Tost allumees, tost estaintes;/ Et jadis fusmes si mignottes!.../ Ainsi en prent a mains et maintes", a stanza from Dunbar's The Tua Mariit Wemen and the Wedo, reading "Silver shouris doun shook, as the sheen crystal,/ And birds shouted in shaw, with their schill/ notis;/ The golden glitterand gleam so gladit their/ heartis,/ They made a glorious glee amang the green/ bewis./ The soft souch of the swyr,/ and soun of the/ streamis,/ The sweet savour of the sward, and singing of/ foulis/ Micht confort ony creature of the kin of Adam", a handwritten clipping that writes out a Scottish witch's chant, which reads "I knok this rag upone this stane / To raise the wind in the divellis name / It sall not lye till I please againe", and a small clipping that states that "Princess Margaret played the part of a dormouse in a scene from 'Alice in Wonderland'. She and Princess Elizabeth did a tap dance". Below the large clipping, Morgan has included a colour photograph of a beetle that looks strikingly like a green leaf, and a colour drawing of a Dragonet flying fish from a cigarette card, with the caption "Player's Cigarettes" and "Dragonet" printed on the clipping. To the right of this clipping, Morgan has drawn small bubbles in blue ink and to the left of the image, he has drawn a small, cartoonish Dragonet in pink ink.

A large colour reproduction of Holbein's "Der Kaufmann George Gisze" (or "The Merchant Georg Gisze") takes up much of this page. Below the clipping Morgan has added a small black and white line drawing of a dog and a baby facing each other across a bone that lies between them, a small clipping that reads "And crocodiles do weep, but not tears. It's just that when their jaws are agape, their eyes water. You weep crocodile tears when your jaws are agape in a good yawn", a small black and white image that is hard to make out, and a small black and white photograph of a relief carving that depicts a running stag, likely an excerpt from a larger work. The bottom of the page is taken up by a colour photograph of several squid and a few small fish swimming.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodles
pages.desc: This page features two excerpts from a Picture Post article with subtitles reading "Sudden Sight - and Sorrow" and "All Faces Look Alike". The clipping describes a 22-year-old girl who was born blind but recovered her sight. The article describes how difficult things like walking up stairs and judging distances became for her, as well as her disappointment in the look of some things, such as animals in the zoo (which she thought would be bigger) and human faces (which she said had less happy expressions that she had expected and which she had difficulty in distinguishing from one another at first). Above and below this clipping Morgan has included small black and white images. The top image is a black and white photograph that appears to show light reflecting on water and the bottom image is difficult to make out, but may also be depicting water. The page also contains a black and white photograph of two stone figures that appear to be sitting together in a vessel, a black and white photograph of a male sculpture standing with his arms extended out to the side and raised at his elbows, a black and white photograph of a carved head, possibly a mask, and a clipping with two black and white photographs of stone relief sculptures, one a detailed dragon's head and one that appears to depict a mermaid, jointly captioned as "Examples of Makara and Khmer sculpture recently excavated and now included among the pieces for exhibition in the new galleries of the Musée Guinet, Paris". Morgan has also included the first several lines from the poem "Song to the Wind", which appears in the Book of Teliesin, reading "Discover thou what is/ The strong creature from before the flood,/ Without flesh, without bone,/ Without vein, without blood,/ Without head, without feet,/ It will neither be older nor younger/ Than at the beginning;/ For fear of a denial,/ There are no rude wants/ With creatures./ Great God! how the sea whitens/ When first it comes!/ Great are its gusts/ When it comes from the south;/ Great are its evaporations/ When it strikes on coasts./ It is in the field, it is in the wood,/ Without hand, and without foot,/ Without signs of old age,/ Though it be co-aeval/ With the five ages or periods". Morgan has decorated the page with blue and pink ink doodles.
